Optimal camera-robot pose estimation in linear time from points and lines

Abstract

Camera pose estimation is a fundamental problem in robotics. This paper focuses on two issues of interest: First, point and line features have complementary advantages, and it is of great value to design a uniform algorithm that can fuse them effectively; Second, with the development of modern front-end techniques, a large number of features can exist in a single image, which presents a potential for highly accurate robot pose estimation. With these observations, we propose AOPnP(L), an optimal linear-time camera-robot pose estimation algorithm from points and lines. Specifically, we represent a line with two distinct points on it and unify the noise model for point and line measurements where noises are added to 2D points in the image. By utilizing PlÃ¼cker coordinates for line parameterization, we formulate a maximum likelihood (ML) problem for combined point and line measurements. To optimally solve the ML problem, AOPnP(L) adopts a two-step estimation scheme. In the first step, a consistent estimate that can converge to the true pose is devised by virtue of bias elimination. In the second step, a single Gauss-Newton iteration is executed to refine the initial estimate. AOPnP(L) features theoretical optimality in the sense that its mean squared error converges to the CramÃ©r-Rao lower bound. Moreover, it owns a linear time complexity. These properties make it well-suited for precision-demanding and real-time robot pose estimation. Extensive experiments are conducted to validate our theoretical developments and demonstrate the superiority of AOPnP(L) in both static localization and dynamic odometry systems.

Guangyang Zeng1, Biqiang Mu2, Qingcheng Zeng3, Yuchen Song1, Chulin Dai1,

Guodong Shi4, and Junfeng Wu1

1School of Data Science, Chinese University of Hong Kong, Shenzhen, Shenzhen, China
2Key Laboratory of Systems and Control, Institute of Systems Science, Academy of Mathematics and Systems Science, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Beijing, China
3System Hub, Hong Kong University of Science and Technology (Guangzhou), Guangzhou, China
4Australian Center for Field Robotics, School of Aerospace, Mechanical and Mechatronic Engineering, The University of Sydney, Sydney, Australia

1 Introduction

1.1 Background

Robot pose estimation refers to inferring the position and orientation of a robot in a specific coordinate system by using sensor measurements. As one of the most fundamental techniques in many robot applications, such as robot navigation, robotic grasping, and simultaneous localization and mapping (SLAM), pose estimation is an important topic in robotics and has been extensively investigatedÂ [1, 2, 3]. In virtue of low cost, high energy efficiency, and the ability to generate high-resolution images with detailed visual context, cameras have been a commonly used sensor for robot pose estimation.

One branch of visual-based methods utilizes the camera projection model and the correspondences between extracted features in the image plane and their 3D positions in the global frame to estimate the camera pose. The most commonly used feature is point features, which corresponds to the perspective-n-point (PnP) problemÂ [4, 5, 6]. Another prevalent feature is line features, and the perspective-n-line (PnL) problem needs to be solvedÂ [7, 8, 9]. On the one hand, line features are more robust in texture-less or repetitive scenes without enough distinctive points. This is likely to occur in man-made structures. While on the other hand, given a line correspondence, there still exists a shift of the line along its direction. In addition, line features may be partially observed due to occlusions. Existing PnL methods are not yet as accurate as PnP ones with enough distinctive point featuresÂ [10]. Therefore, some works utilize both point and line features for camera pose estimation, which yields the so-called PnPL problemÂ [10, 11].

Accurate pose acquisition is crucial for many modern robot applications, such as surgical robotsÂ [12], implicit mapping based on neural radiance fieldsÂ [13], and large-scale SLAMÂ [14]. It is noteworthy that with the development of feature detectors and descriptors, a large number of features can exist in a single image, which brings great potential for highly precise pose estimation. One idea to fully exploit the large sample feature measurements is to devise a consistent and asymptotically efficient estimate, which converges to the true pose with a minimum covariance as the feature number increases. We note that the existing methods generally ignore the modeling of measurement noises and lack elaborate design from the perspective of statistical estimation theory. As a result, they are usually inconsistent due to the nonlinear property of the pinhole camera projection model. In what follows, we will give a literature review.

1.2 Related work

PnP problem: As points are easier to handle mathematically than lines in camera pose estimation, the PnP problem was first studied. Some works consider a fixed number of points. Since the degree of the pose is six and each point correspondence produces two independent equations, the minimal case is n=3ğ‘›3n=3italic_n = 3, which corresponds to the P3P problemÂ [15, 16]. There are also P4PÂ [17] and P5PÂ [18] solvers for n=4ğ‘›4n=4italic_n = 4 and n=5ğ‘›5n=5italic_n = 5, respectively. These fix-point solutions are sensitive to noises and generally embedded in a random sample consensus (RANSAC) framework for robust estimation. Most PnP solvers, however, can cope with a flexible number of points by formulating a least-squares problem. The optimization methods can be categorized into iterative and noniterative algorithms. Iterative methods start with an initial value and solve the problem using an iterative algorithm, e.g., the GN and Levenberg-Marquardt (LM) methodsÂ [19, 20, 6]. Due to the nonconvexity of the problem, without a good initialization, iterative methods can only result in a local minimum. Early noniterative methods usually have a high computational complexity. The first well-known Oâ¢(n)ğ‘‚ğ‘›O(n)italic_O ( italic_n ) solver is EPnPÂ [4], which utilizes linearization techniques. Direct linear transformation (DLT) is another linear formulationÂ [21]. Apart from linearization techniques, polynomial solvers that do not ignore the constraints on rotation have become mainstreamÂ [22, 23, 24]. They estimate the pose by solving a system of polynomial equations and can generally achieve a better performance than linear methods which ignore constraints. Noniterative solutions are sometimes used as the initial value for iterative algorithms.

PnL problem: The early PnL research emerged in the 1990s for the reason that line features are generally more robust than point features, especially in texture-less or repetitive scenes. Note that each line correspondence provides two independent equations. Thus, the minimal case is also n=3ğ‘›3n=3italic_n = 3, which results in the P3L problemÂ [25]. For nonminimal flexible cases, early works mainly focused on error function formulation and iterative solutionsÂ [26]. Because of nonconvexity, iterative methods also face the possibility of converging to local minimaÂ [27, 28]. In terms of noniterative methods, the DLT formulations can vary for different line parameterizations. The classical DLT method parameterizes a 3D line by its two endpoints and constructs homogeneous equations based on the constraint that the projection of the endpoints should be on the 2D lineÂ [21]. PÅ™ibyl et al.Â [29] used the PlÃ¼cker coordinates to represent a 3D line and proposed a novel DLT method. Compared with linear methods, polynomial solvers that consider the rotation constraints need fewer lines and can usually obtain a more accurate solution for a small nğ‘›nitalic_nÂ [30, 31, 7, 32]. However, they are more computationally demanding and may encounter numerical problemsÂ [26].

PnPL problem: There is a limited number of approaches that estimate the camera pose utilizing both points and lines. The minimal case was addressed inÂ [33, 34]. For nonminimal cases, DLT methods are straightforward since the homogeneous equations for both points and lines have already been established in previous worksÂ [21]. Extending the existing PnP methods to the PnPL counterparts by elaborately formulating the line projection error is another practical approach, for instance, Vakhitov et al.Â [10] developed EPnP and OPnP to EPnPL and OPnPL, respectively, and EPnP and DLS are extended to EPnPLU and DLSLU, respectively inÂ [11]. Li et al. adopted the Cayley parametrization for the rotation matrix and constructed a polynomial system by the first-order optimality conditionÂ [35]. Recently, certifiably optimal solvers were proposed with sum-of-squares relaxationÂ [36] and semidefinite relaxationÂ [37].

Uncertainty-aware PnP(L) problem: Most existing works do not consider measurement noises contained in features. Since the extracted features are inevitably corrupted by noises, the uncertainty-aware methods that explicitly model noises are likely to achieve higher accuracy. Among them, the uncertainty in 2D features was considered and a weighted least-squares problem by using the squared Mahalanobis distance was formulated inÂ [30, 38, 5, 35, 11]. Recently, Vakhitov et al.Â [11] estimated both 2D and 3D uncertainty to enhance estimation performance. However, it needs prior information of an initial pose or the average scene depth. We remark that although the above methods have considered the noise model, they do not analyze noise propagation and the effect on the final estimate. The lack of statistical analysis and optimization from the perspective of estimation theory makes them not asymptotically unbiased and consistent. CPnPÂ [39] can obtain a consistent estimate, however, it cannot theoretically guarantee asymptotic efficiency, and it is only applicable to point features.

1.3 Main results

This paper investigates the camera-robot pose estimation problem with large sample features. We propose a uniform estimator that can take point features, line features, or both as measurements. In terms of estimation accuracy, the proposed estimator is optimal in the large sample caseâ€”it optimally solves the maximum likelihood (ML) problem and its covariance reaches a theoretical lower bound as the number of features increases. In terms of computation speed, it has a linear time complexityâ€”the consuming time linearly grows with respect to the feature number. With a large number of features, our estimator provides an appropriate solution for highly precise and real-time robot pose estimation.

The main contributions of this paper are summarized as follows:

  1. (i).ğ‘–(i).( italic_i ) .

    By representing a line with two distinct points on it, we unify the camera noise model in which measurement noises are added to 2D point projections in the image. In addition, by utilizing the PlÃ¼cker coordinates for line parameterization, we construct the residuals for line features and formulate a uniform ML problem for combined point and line measurements.

  2. (iâ¢i).ğ‘–ğ‘–(ii).( italic_i italic_i ) .

    We propose a uniform pose estimation framework for combined point and line measurements. The framework has linear time complexity and is asymptotically optimal. The core of the framework is a two-step estimation scheme, which asymptotically solves the ML problem. In the first step, we devise a consistent pose estimate that converges to the true pose as features increase. In the second step, we execute a single Gauss-Newton (GN) iteration and prove that the refined estimate asymptotically reaches the theoretical lower boundâ€”CramÃ©r-Rao bound (CRB).

  3. (iâ¢iâ¢i).ğ‘–ğ‘–ğ‘–(iii).( italic_i italic_i italic_i ) .

    The framework also incorporates two modules to facilitate the stability and applicability of the estimator in real scenarios. The first is data preprocessing, which normalizes the scale of data to promote numerical stability. The second is consistent noise variance estimation by solving a generalized eigenvalue problem, which is a prerequisite for the proposed two-step pose estimator in case of unknown noise statistical characteristics.

  4. (iâ¢v).ğ‘–ğ‘£(iv).( italic_i italic_v ) .

    We perform extensive experiments with both synthetic and real-world data to verify the theoretical developments and compare the proposed estimator with state-of-the-art ones. The experiment results demonstrate the superiority of our algorithm in terms of estimation accuracy and computation speed, not only for robot relocalization in a known map but also for SLAM in an unknown environment.

2 Preliminaries

To facilitate the readability of the subsequent technical part, in this section, we give some preliminaries on notations, probability and statistics, rigid transformation, and GN iterations on the manifold of SOâ¢(3)SO3{\rm SO}(3)roman_SO ( 3 ).

For a quantity ğ±ğ±{\bf x}bold_x corrupted by noise, we use ğ±osuperscriptğ±ğ‘œ{\bf x}^{o}bold_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_o end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT to denote its noise-free counterpart.

2.2 Some notions in probability and statistics

Convergence in probability. Consistent and nğ‘›\sqrt{n}square-root start_ARG italic_n end_ARG-consistent estimate. It is noteworthy that nğ‘›\sqrt{n}square-root start_ARG italic_n end_ARG-consistent includes two implications: The estimate ğœ½^nsubscript^ğœ½ğ‘›\hat{\bm{\theta}}_{n}over^ start_ARG bold_italic_Î¸ end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is consistent, i.e., ğœ½^nsubscript^ğœ½ğ‘›\hat{\bm{\theta}}_{n}over^ start_ARG bold_italic_Î¸ end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT converges to ğœ½osuperscriptğœ½ğ‘œ{\bm{\theta}}^{o}bold_italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_o end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT in probability; The convergence rate is 1/n1ğ‘›1/\sqrt{n}1 / square-root start_ARG italic_n end_ARG.

(Asymptotically) unbiased estimate. The bias of an estimate ğœ½^nsubscript^ğœ½ğ‘›\hat{\bm{\theta}}_{n}over^ start_ARG bold_italic_Î¸ end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is equal to its expectation minus the true value, i.e., Biasâ¢(ğœ½^n)=ğ”¼â¢[ğœ½^n]âˆ’ğœ½oBiassubscript^ğœ½ğ‘›ğ”¼delimited-[]subscript^ğœ½ğ‘›superscriptğœ½ğ‘œ{\rm Bias}(\hat{\bm{\theta}}_{n})=\mathbb{E}[\hat{\bm{\theta}}_{n}]-{\bm{% \theta}}^{o}roman_Bias ( over^ start_ARG bold_italic_Î¸ end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) = blackboard_E [ over^ start_ARG bold_italic_Î¸ end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] - bold_italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_o end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. If Biasâ¢(ğœ½^n)=0Biassubscript^ğœ½ğ‘›0{\rm Bias}(\hat{\bm{\theta}}_{n})=0roman_Bias ( over^ start_ARG bold_italic_Î¸ end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) = 0, we call ğœ½^nsubscript^ğœ½ğ‘›\hat{\bm{\theta}}_{n}over^ start_ARG bold_italic_Î¸ end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT an unbiased estimate of ğœ½osuperscriptğœ½ğ‘œ{\bm{\theta}}^{o}bold_italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_o end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. In particular, if limnâ†’âˆBiasâ¢(ğœ½^n)=0subscriptâ†’ğ‘›Biassubscript^ğœ½ğ‘›0\lim_{n\rightarrow\infty}{\rm Bias}(\hat{\bm{\theta}}_{n})=0roman_lim start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n â†’ âˆ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_Bias ( over^ start_ARG bold_italic_Î¸ end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) = 0, we call ğœ½^nsubscript^ğœ½ğ‘›\hat{\bm{\theta}}_{n}over^ start_ARG bold_italic_Î¸ end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT an asymptotically unbiased estimate. It is noteworthy that an asymptotically unbiased estimate ğœ½^nsubscript^ğœ½ğ‘›\hat{\bm{\theta}}_{n}over^ start_ARG bold_italic_Î¸ end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT may not necessarily be unbiased given a finite nğ‘›nitalic_n.

(Asymptotically) efficient estimate. An unbiased estimate ğœ½^nsubscript^ğœ½ğ‘›\hat{\bm{\theta}}_{n}over^ start_ARG bold_italic_Î¸ end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is said to be efficient if its covariance covâ¢(ğœ½^n)covsubscript^ğœ½ğ‘›{\rm cov}(\hat{\bm{\theta}}_{n})roman_cov ( over^ start_ARG bold_italic_Î¸ end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) equals the theoretical lower bound â€” CramÃ©r-Rao bound (CRB). In particular, ğœ½^nsubscript^ğœ½ğ‘›\hat{\bm{\theta}}_{n}over^ start_ARG bold_italic_Î¸ end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is called asymptotically efficient if it is asymptotically unbiased, and limnâ†’âˆcovâ¢(nâ¢ğœ½^n)=nâ¢CRBsubscriptâ†’ğ‘›covğ‘›subscript^ğœ½ğ‘›ğ‘›CRB\lim_{n\rightarrow\infty}{\rm cov}(\sqrt{n}\hat{\bm{\theta}}_{n})=n{\rm CRB}roman_lim start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n â†’ âˆ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_cov ( square-root start_ARG italic_n end_ARG over^ start_ARG bold_italic_Î¸ end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) = italic_n roman_CRB. CRB can be obtained from the Fisher information matrix ğ…ğ…\bf Fbold_F as CRB=ğ…âˆ’1CRBsuperscriptğ…1{\rm CRB}={\bf F}^{-1}roman_CRB = bold_F start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, and ğ…ğ…\bf Fbold_F is the covariance of the derivative of the log-likelihood function â„“â¢(ğœ½;ğ’´n)â„“ğœ½subscriptğ’´ğ‘›\ell({\bm{\theta}};\mathcal{Y}_{n})roman_â„“ ( bold_italic_Î¸ ; caligraphic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) evaluated at the true parameter ğœ½osuperscriptğœ½ğ‘œ{\bm{\theta}}^{o}bold_italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_o end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT:

ğ…=ğ”¼â¢[âˆ‚â„“â¢(ğœ½;ğ’´n)âˆ‚ğœ½â¢âˆ‚â„“â¢(ğœ½;ğ’´n)âˆ‚ğœ½âŠ¤|ğœ½o].ğ…ğ”¼delimited-[]conditionalâ„“ğœ½subscriptğ’´ğ‘›ğœ½â„“ğœ½subscriptğ’´ğ‘›superscriptğœ½topsuperscriptğœ½ğ‘œ{\bf F}=\mathbb{E}\left[\frac{\partial\ell({\bm{\theta}};\mathcal{Y}_{n})}{% \partial{\bm{\theta}}}\frac{\partial\ell({\bm{\theta}};\mathcal{Y}_{n})}{% \partial{\bm{\theta}}^{\top}}\bigg{|}{\bm{\theta}}^{o}\right].bold_F = blackboard_E [ divide start_ARG âˆ‚ roman_â„“ ( bold_italic_Î¸ ; caligraphic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_ARG start_ARG âˆ‚ bold_italic_Î¸ end_ARG divide start_ARG âˆ‚ roman_â„“ ( bold_italic_Î¸ ; caligraphic_Y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_ARG start_ARG âˆ‚ bold_italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âŠ¤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG | bold_italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_o end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ] .

2.3 Rigid transformation

The (proper) rigid transformations, or said relative poses, include rotations and translations. In the 3D Euclidean space, the translation is depicted by a vector ğ­âˆˆâ„3ğ­superscriptâ„3{\bf t}\in\mathbb{R}^{3}bold_t âˆˆ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. The rotation can be characterized by a rotation matrix ğ‘ğ‘\bf Rbold_R. Specifically, rotation matrices belong to the special orthogonal group

SOâ¢(3)={ğ‘âˆˆâ„3Ã—3âˆ£ğ‘âŠ¤â¢ğ‘=ğˆ3,detâ¢(ğ‘)=1}.SO3conditional-setğ‘superscriptâ„33formulae-sequencesuperscriptğ‘topğ‘subscriptğˆ3detğ‘1{\rm SO}(3)=\{{\bf R}\in\mathbb{R}^{3\times 3}\mid{\bf R}^{\top}{\bf R}={\bf I% }_{3},{\rm det}({\bf R})=1\}.roman_SO ( 3 ) = { bold_R âˆˆ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 3 Ã— 3 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ£ bold_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âŠ¤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_R = bold_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , roman_det ( bold_R ) = 1 } .

The group operation is the usual matrix multiplication, and the inverse is the matrix transpose. The group SOâ¢(3)SO3{\rm SO}(3)roman_SO ( 3 ) forms a smooth manifold, and the tangent space to the manifold (at the identity) is denoted as the Lie algebra ğ”°â¢ğ”¬â¢(3)ğ”°ğ”¬3\mathfrak{so}(3)fraktur_s fraktur_o ( 3 ) which is comprised of all 3Ã—3333\times 33 Ã— 3 skew-symmetric matrices. Every 3Ã—3333\times 33 Ã— 3 skew-symmetric matrix can be generated from a vector ğ¬âˆˆâ„3ğ¬superscriptâ„3{\bf s}\in\mathbb{R}^{3}bold_s âˆˆ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT via the hat operator:

ğ¬âˆ§=[s1s2s3]âˆ§=[0âˆ’s3s2s30âˆ’s1âˆ’s2s10]âˆˆğ”°â¢ğ”¬â¢(3).superscriptğ¬superscriptmatrixsubscriptğ‘ 1subscriptğ‘ 2subscriptğ‘ 3matrix0subscriptğ‘ 3subscriptğ‘ 2subscriptğ‘ 30subscriptğ‘ 1subscriptğ‘ 2subscriptğ‘ 10ğ”°ğ”¬3{\bf s}^{\wedge}=\begin{bmatrix}s_{1}\\ s_{2}\\ s_{3}\end{bmatrix}^{\wedge}=\begin{bmatrix}0&-s_{3}&s_{2}\\ s_{3}&0&-s_{1}\\ -s_{2}&s_{1}&0\end{bmatrix}\in\mathfrak{so}(3).bold_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ§ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = [ start_ARG start_ROW start_CELL italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_CELL end_ROW end_ARG ] start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ§ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = [ start_ARG start_ROW start_CELL 0 end_CELL start_CELL - italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_CELL start_CELL italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_CELL start_CELL 0 end_CELL start_CELL - italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL - italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_CELL start_CELL italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_CELL start_CELL 0 end_CELL end_ROW end_ARG ] âˆˆ fraktur_s fraktur_o ( 3 ) . (1)

Conversely, the vee operator retrieves the vector from a skew-symmetric matrix:

(ğ¬âˆ§)âˆ¨=ğ¬âˆˆâ„3.superscriptsuperscriptğ¬ğ¬superscriptâ„3\left({\bf s}^{\wedge}\right)^{\vee}={\bf s}\in\mathbb{R}^{3}.( bold_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ§ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ¨ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = bold_s âˆˆ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT .

The exponential map exp:ğ”°â¢ğ”¬â¢(3)â†’SOâ¢(3):expâ†’ğ”°ğ”¬3SO3{\rm exp}:\mathfrak{so}(3)\rightarrow{\rm SO}(3)roman_exp : fraktur_s fraktur_o ( 3 ) â†’ roman_SO ( 3 ), which coincides with standard matrix exponential, associates an element in the Lie algebra to a rotation matrix. Specifically, Rodriguesâ€™ rotation formula reads that

expâ¢(ğ¬âˆ§)=ğˆ3+sinâ¡(â€–ğ¬â€–)â€–ğ¬â€–â¢ğ¬âˆ§+1âˆ’cosâ¡(â€–ğ¬â€–)â€–ğ¬â€–2â¢(ğ¬âˆ§)2.expsuperscriptğ¬subscriptğˆ3normğ¬normğ¬superscriptğ¬1normğ¬superscriptnormğ¬2superscriptsuperscriptğ¬2{\rm exp}\left({\bf s}^{\wedge}\right)={\bf I}_{3}+\frac{\sin(\|{\bf s}\|)}{\|% {\bf s}\|}{\bf s}^{\wedge}+\frac{1-\cos(\|{\bf s}\|)}{\|{\bf s}\|^{2}}\left({% \bf s}^{\wedge}\right)^{2}.roman_exp ( bold_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ§ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) = bold_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + divide start_ARG roman_sin ( âˆ¥ bold_s âˆ¥ ) end_ARG start_ARG âˆ¥ bold_s âˆ¥ end_ARG bold_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ§ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + divide start_ARG 1 - roman_cos ( âˆ¥ bold_s âˆ¥ ) end_ARG start_ARG âˆ¥ bold_s âˆ¥ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG ( bold_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ§ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT .

Conversely, the logarithm map log:SOâ¢(3)â†’ğ”°â¢ğ”¬â¢(3):logâ†’SO3ğ”°ğ”¬3{\rm log}:{\rm SO}(3)\rightarrow\mathfrak{so}(3)roman_log : roman_SO ( 3 ) â†’ fraktur_s fraktur_o ( 3 ) associates a rotation matrix ğ‘â‰ ğˆ3ğ‘subscriptğˆ3{\bf R}\neq{\bf I}_{3}bold_R â‰  bold_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT to a skew-symmetric matrix:

logâ¢(ğ‘)=Ï•â¢(ğ‘âˆ’ğ‘âŠ¤)2â¢sinâ¡(Ï•)withÏ•=cosâˆ’1â¡(trâ¢(ğ‘)âˆ’ğŸ2).formulae-sequencelogğ‘italic-Ï•ğ‘superscriptğ‘top2italic-Ï•withitalic-Ï•superscript1trğ‘12{\rm log}({\bf R})=\frac{\phi({\bf R}-{\bf R}^{\top})}{2\sin(\phi)}\leavevmode% \nobreak\ \leavevmode\nobreak\ \text{with}\leavevmode\nobreak\ \leavevmode% \nobreak\ \phi=\cos^{-1}\left(\frac{{\rm tr}(\bf R)-1}{2}\right).roman_log ( bold_R ) = divide start_ARG italic_Ï• ( bold_R - bold_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âŠ¤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) end_ARG start_ARG 2 roman_sin ( italic_Ï• ) end_ARG with italic_Ï• = roman_cos start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( divide start_ARG roman_tr ( bold_R ) - bold_1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG ) .

One can further write logâ¢(ğ‘)âˆ¨=Ï•â¢ğ§logsuperscriptğ‘italic-Ï•ğ§{\rm log}({\bf R})^{\vee}=\phi{\bf n}roman_log ( bold_R ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ¨ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = italic_Ï• bold_n, where the unit vector ğ§ğ§\bf nbold_n denotes the rotation axis, and Ï•italic-Ï•\phiitalic_Ï• is the rotation angle. It is noteworthy that the exponential map is bijective if we confine its domain to the open ball {ğ¬âˆ£â€–ğ¬â€–<Ï€}conditional-setğ¬normğ¬ğœ‹\{{\bf s}\mid\|{\bf s}\|<\pi\}{ bold_s âˆ£ âˆ¥ bold_s âˆ¥ < italic_Ï€ }, and its inverse is the logarithm map.

Suppose the relative pose of the second frame with respect to (w.r.t.) the first frame is (ğ‘,ğ­)ğ‘ğ­({\bf R},{\bf t})( bold_R , bold_t ), and the coordinates of a 3D point in the second frame is ğ—ğ—{\bf X}bold_X. Then the coordinates of the point in the first frame is ğ‘ğ—+ğ­ğ‘ğ—ğ­{\bf R}{\bf X}+{\bf t}bold_RX + bold_t.

2.4 Gauss-Newton method on SOâ¢(3)SO3{\rm SO}(3)roman_SO ( 3 )

The GN method is usually applied to iteratively solve a nonlinear least-squares optimization problem. It is an approximation of Newtonâ€™s method and has the advantage that second derivatives are not required. Specifically, it linearly approximates residuals through the first-order Taylor polynomial, and then optimally solves the resulting quadratic problem with a closed-form solution. When it comes to an optimization problem over the manifold of SOâ¢(3)SO3{\rm SO}(3)roman_SO ( 3 ), the standard GN method needs to be modified with some techniques to ensure that the updated value after each iteration also belongs to SOâ¢(3)SO3{\rm SO}(3)roman_SO ( 3 ).

Consider the following optimization problem:

minimizeğ‘âˆˆSOâ¢(3),ğ­âˆˆâ„3â€–ğ«â¢(ğ‘,ğ­)â€–2.subscriptminimizeformulae-sequenceğ‘SO3ğ­superscriptâ„3superscriptnormğ«ğ‘ğ­2\mathop{\rm minimize}\limits_{{\bf R}\in{\rm SO}(3),{\bf t}\in\mathbb{R}^{3}}% \leavevmode\nobreak\ \|{\bf r}({\bf R},{\bf t})\|^{2}.roman_minimize start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_R âˆˆ roman_SO ( 3 ) , bold_t âˆˆ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¥ bold_r ( bold_R , bold_t ) âˆ¥ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT . (2)

Note that the rotation in the 3D space has three degrees, while the rotation matrix ğ‘ğ‘\bf Rbold_R has nine elements, which is overparameterized. If we directly optimize over ğ‘ğ‘\bf Rbold_R, the Jacobian matrix may not have full column rank, and the updated value of ğ‘ğ‘\bf Rbold_R is generally not an element of SOâ¢(3)SO3{\rm SO}(3)roman_SO ( 3 ). To overcome this issue, we can introduce a retraction â„›ğ‘subscriptâ„›ğ‘\mathcal{R}_{\bf R}caligraphic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_R end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, which is a bijective map between an element ğ¬ğ¬{\bf s}bold_s of the tangent space at ğ‘ğ‘\bf Rbold_R and a neighborhood of ğ‘âˆˆSOâ¢(3)ğ‘SO3{\bf R}\in{\rm SO}(3)bold_R âˆˆ roman_SO ( 3 ). The retraction used in this paper is

â„›ğ‘â¢(ğ¬)=ğ‘â¢expâ¢(ğ¬âˆ§),ğ¬âˆˆâ„3.formulae-sequencesubscriptâ„›ğ‘ğ¬ğ‘expsuperscriptğ¬ğ¬superscriptâ„3\mathcal{R}_{\bf R}({\bf s})={\bf R}\leavevmode\nobreak\ {\rm exp}({\bf s}^{% \wedge}),\leavevmode\nobreak\ \leavevmode\nobreak\ {\bf s}\in\mathbb{R}^{3}.caligraphic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_R end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_s ) = bold_R roman_exp ( bold_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ§ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) , bold_s âˆˆ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT . (3)

Given an initial estimate ğ‘^âˆˆSOâ¢(3)^ğ‘SO3\hat{\bf R}\in{\rm SO}(3)over^ start_ARG bold_R end_ARG âˆˆ roman_SO ( 3 ), using this retraction, the original problemÂ (2) is converted into

minimizeğ¬,ğ­âˆˆâ„3â€–ğ«â¢(â„›ğ‘^â¢(ğ¬),ğ­)â€–2.subscriptminimizeğ¬ğ­superscriptâ„3superscriptnormğ«subscriptâ„›^ğ‘ğ¬ğ­2\mathop{\rm minimize}\limits_{{\bf s,t}\in\mathbb{R}^{3}}\leavevmode\nobreak\ % \|{\bf r}\left(\mathcal{R}_{\hat{\bf R}}({\bf s}),{\bf t}\right)\|^{2}.roman_minimize start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_s , bold_t âˆˆ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¥ bold_r ( caligraphic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT over^ start_ARG bold_R end_ARG end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_s ) , bold_t ) âˆ¥ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT . (4)

The above reparameterization is usually called lifting. The main idea is to work in the tangent space defined at the current estimate ğ‘^^ğ‘\hat{\bf R}over^ start_ARG bold_R end_ARG, which locally behaves as an Euclidean space. The Euclidean space has three dimensions, coinciding with the degree of a 3D rotation. Note that problemÂ (4) is an optimization problem over an Euclidean space and thus can be solved utilizing the standard GN method. Once an updated ğ¬^^ğ¬\hat{\bf s}over^ start_ARG bold_s end_ARG is produced, we can obtain a refined rotation matrix â„›ğ‘^â¢(ğ¬^)subscriptâ„›^ğ‘^ğ¬\mathcal{R}_{\hat{\bf R}}(\hat{\bf s})caligraphic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT over^ start_ARG bold_R end_ARG end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( over^ start_ARG bold_s end_ARG ) which naturally belongs to SOâ¢(3)SO3{\rm SO}(3)roman_SO ( 3 ) via the retractionÂ (3).

3 Problem formulation

3.1 Point and line models

We consider a pinhole camera model and assume the intrinsic matrix of the camera is known by some means, such as a prior calibration. As such, without loss of generality, we assume the focal length f=1ğ‘“1f=1italic_f = 1 and utilize normalized image coordinates to represent points in the image plane. Let {ğ’²}ğ’²\{\mathcal{W}\}{ caligraphic_W } and {ğ’}ğ’\{\mathcal{C}\}{ caligraphic_C } denote the world coordinate frame and camera coordinate frame, respectively. To estimate the relative pose of {ğ’²}ğ’²\{\mathcal{W}\}{ caligraphic_W } w.r.t. {ğ’}ğ’\{\mathcal{C}\}{ caligraphic_C }, which is denoted by a rotation matrix ğ‘osuperscriptğ‘ğ‘œ{\bf R}^{o}bold_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_o end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and a translation vector ğ­osuperscriptğ­ğ‘œ{\bf t}^{o}bold_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_o end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, suppose that there exist nğ‘›nitalic_n point correspondences {(ğ—i,ğ±i)}i=1nsuperscriptsubscriptsubscriptğ—ğ‘–subscriptğ±ğ‘–ğ‘–1ğ‘›\{({\bf X}_{i},{\bf x}_{i})\}_{i=1}^{n}{ ( bold_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) } start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and mğ‘šmitalic_m line correspondences {(ğ‹j,ğ¥j)}j=1msuperscriptsubscriptsubscriptğ‹ğ‘—subscriptğ¥ğ‘—ğ‘—1ğ‘š\{({\bf L}_{j},{\bf l}_{j})\}_{j=1}^{m}{ ( bold_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , bold_l start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) } start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Here, ğ—iâˆˆâ„3subscriptğ—ğ‘–superscriptâ„3{\bf X}_{i}\in\mathbb{R}^{3}bold_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆˆ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT denotes the iğ‘–iitalic_i-th 3D point in the world frame, and ğ±iâˆˆâ„2subscriptğ±ğ‘–superscriptâ„2{\bf x}_{i}\in\mathbb{R}^{2}bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆˆ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT represents its 2D projection (in the form of normalized image coordinates) in the image plane. Let ğ—ihâ‰œ[ğ—iâŠ¤â¢ 1]âŠ¤â‰œsuperscriptsubscriptğ—ğ‘–â„superscriptdelimited-[]superscriptsubscriptğ—ğ‘–top1top{\bf X}_{i}^{h}\triangleq[{\bf X}_{i}^{\top}\leavevmode\nobreak\ 1]^{\top}bold_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_h end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‰œ [ bold_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âŠ¤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 ] start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âŠ¤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and ğ±ihâ‰œ[ğ±iâŠ¤â¢ 1]âŠ¤â‰œsuperscriptsubscriptğ±ğ‘–â„superscriptdelimited-[]superscriptsubscriptğ±ğ‘–top1top{\bf x}_{i}^{h}\triangleq[{\bf x}_{i}^{\top}\leavevmode\nobreak\ 1]^{\top}bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_h end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‰œ [ bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âŠ¤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 ] start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âŠ¤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT be the corresponding homogeneous coordinates. As illustrated in FigureÂ 1, we have the following relationship:

ğ±ihâ‰ˆğ‘oâ¢ğ—i+ğ­o=[ğ‘oğ­o]â¢ğ—ih,superscriptsubscriptğ±ğ‘–â„superscriptğ‘ğ‘œsubscriptğ—ğ‘–superscriptğ­ğ‘œsuperscriptğ‘ğ‘œsuperscriptğ­ğ‘œsuperscriptsubscriptğ—ğ‘–â„{\bf x}_{i}^{h}\approx{\bf R}^{o}{\bf X}_{i}+{\bf t}^{o}=[{\bf R}^{o}% \leavevmode\nobreak\ \leavevmode\nobreak\ {\bf t}^{o}]{\bf X}_{i}^{h},bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_h end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‰ˆ bold_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_o end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + bold_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_o end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = [ bold_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_o end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_o end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ] bold_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_h end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , (5)

where â‰ˆ\approxâ‰ˆ denotes the equivalence relation that equates two values only with a nonzero scale difference. More specifically, the exact point projection function is given byÂ [39]

ğ±i=hğ‘o,ğ­oâ¢(ğ—i)â‰œğ„â¢(ğ‘oâ¢ğ—i+ğ­o)ğ3âŠ¤â¢(ğ‘oâ¢ğ—i+ğ­o),subscriptğ±ğ‘–subscriptâ„superscriptğ‘ğ‘œsuperscriptğ­ğ‘œsubscriptğ—ğ‘–â‰œğ„superscriptğ‘ğ‘œsubscriptğ—ğ‘–superscriptğ­ğ‘œsuperscriptsubscriptğ3topsuperscriptğ‘ğ‘œsubscriptğ—ğ‘–superscriptğ­ğ‘œ{\bf x}_{i}=h_{{\bf R}^{o},{\bf t}^{o}}({\bf X}_{i})\triangleq\frac{{\bf E}({% \bf R}^{o}{\bf X}_{i}+{\bf t}^{o})}{{\bf e}_{3}^{\top}({\bf R}^{o}{\bf X}_{i}+% {\bf t}^{o})},bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_o end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , bold_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_o end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) â‰œ divide start_ARG bold_E ( bold_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_o end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + bold_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_o end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) end_ARG start_ARG bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âŠ¤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( bold_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_o end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + bold_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_o end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) end_ARG , (6)

where ğ„=[ğ1â¢ğ2]âŠ¤ğ„superscriptdelimited-[]subscriptğ1subscriptğ2top{\bf E}=[{\bf e}_{1}\leavevmode\nobreak\ {\bf e}_{2}]^{\top}bold_E = [ bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âŠ¤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, and ğisubscriptğğ‘–{\bf e}_{i}bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT denotes the unit vector whose iğ‘–iitalic_i-th element is 1111.

For the jğ‘—jitalic_j-th line ğ‹jsubscriptğ‹ğ‘—{\bf L}_{j}bold_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT in the world frame, we denote it by two distinct points ğjsubscriptğğ‘—{\bf P}_{j}bold_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and ğjsubscriptğğ‘—{\bf Q}_{j}bold_Q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT on it and parameterize it with PlÃ¼cker coordinatesÂ [21] as follows:

ğ‹jâ‰œ[(ğjÃ—ğj)âŠ¤(ğjâˆ’ğj)âŠ¤]âŠ¤âˆˆâ„6.â‰œsubscriptğ‹ğ‘—superscriptsuperscriptsubscriptğğ‘—subscriptğğ‘—topsuperscriptsubscriptğğ‘—subscriptğğ‘—toptopsuperscriptâ„6{\bf L}_{j}\triangleq\left[({\bf P}_{j}\times{\bf Q}_{j})^{\top}\leavevmode% \nobreak\ \leavevmode\nobreak\ ({\bf Q}_{j}-{\bf P}_{j})^{\top}\right]^{\top}% \in\mathbb{R}^{6}.bold_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‰œ [ ( bold_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT Ã— bold_Q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âŠ¤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( bold_Q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - bold_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âŠ¤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ] start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âŠ¤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆˆ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 6 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT .

Note that a line in the 3D space has a degree of four. Hence, the PlÃ¼cker coordinates representation is overparameterized. Nevertheless, it is widely used in geometric computer vision since the projection of a line under this parameterization exhibits a linear formÂ [21, 29, 40]. Similarly, we denote ğ¥jsubscriptğ¥ğ‘—{\bf l}_{j}bold_l start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT (the projection of ğ‹jsubscriptğ‹ğ‘—{\bf L}_{j}bold_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT) by two distinct points ğ©jsubscriptğ©ğ‘—{\bf p}_{j}bold_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and ğªjsubscriptğªğ‘—{\bf q}_{j}bold_q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT on it and parameterize it as ğ¥jâ‰œğ©jhÃ—ğªjhâˆˆâ„3â‰œsubscriptğ¥ğ‘—superscriptsubscriptğ©ğ‘—â„superscriptsubscriptğªğ‘—â„superscriptâ„3{\bf l}_{j}\triangleq{\bf p}_{j}^{h}\times{\bf q}_{j}^{h}\in\mathbb{R}^{3}bold_l start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‰œ bold_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_h end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT Ã— bold_q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_h end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆˆ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, where ğ©jhâ‰œ[ğ©jâŠ¤â¢ 1]âŠ¤â‰œsuperscriptsubscriptğ©ğ‘—â„superscriptdelimited-[]superscriptsubscriptğ©ğ‘—top1top{\bf p}_{j}^{h}\triangleq[{\bf p}_{j}^{\top}\leavevmode\nobreak\ 1]^{\top}bold_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_h end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‰œ [ bold_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âŠ¤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 ] start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âŠ¤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and ğªjhâ‰œ[ğªjâŠ¤â¢ 1]âŠ¤â‰œsuperscriptsubscriptğªğ‘—â„superscriptdelimited-[]superscriptsubscriptğªğ‘—top1top{\bf q}_{j}^{h}\triangleq[{\bf q}_{j}^{\top}\leavevmode\nobreak\ 1]^{\top}bold_q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_h end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‰œ [ bold_q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âŠ¤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 ] start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âŠ¤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Then, the linear line projection is expressed asÂ [21]

ğ¥jâ‰ˆ[ğ‘oğ­oâˆ§â¢ğ‘o]â¢ğ‹j,subscriptğ¥ğ‘—superscriptğ‘ğ‘œsuperscriptğ­limit-fromğ‘œsuperscriptğ‘ğ‘œsubscriptğ‹ğ‘—{\bf l}_{j}\approx\left[{\bf R}^{o}\leavevmode\nobreak\ \leavevmode\nobreak\ {% \bf t}^{o\wedge}{\bf R}^{o}\right]{\bf L}_{j},bold_l start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‰ˆ [ bold_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_o end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_o âˆ§ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_o end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ] bold_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , (7)

where the hat operator âˆ§\wedgeâˆ§ has been defined inÂ (1). It is worth mentioning that for the jğ‘—jitalic_j-th line correspondence (ğ‹j,ğ¥j)subscriptğ‹ğ‘—subscriptğ¥ğ‘—({\bf L}_{j},{\bf l}_{j})( bold_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , bold_l start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ), their endpoints generally do not form point correspondences, i.e., ğ©jsubscriptğ©ğ‘—{\bf p}_{j}bold_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and ğªjsubscriptğªğ‘—{\bf q}_{j}bold_q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT are generally not the projections of ğjsubscriptğğ‘—{\bf P}_{j}bold_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and ğjsubscriptğğ‘—{\bf Q}_{j}bold_Q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, as shown in FigureÂ 1.

3.2 ML problem

In the previous subsection, we have introduced the models of points and lines and the ideal projection geometry. In this part, we explicitly take measurement noises (or projection noises) into account and construct an ML problem from both point and line features. Specifically, we suppose noises are added to the projections of points. That is,

ğ±isubscriptğ±ğ‘–\displaystyle{\bf x}_{i}bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT =hğ‘o,ğ­oâ¢(ğ—i)+Ïµğ±i=ğ±io+Ïµğ±i,absentsubscriptâ„superscriptğ‘ğ‘œsuperscriptğ­ğ‘œsubscriptğ—ğ‘–subscriptbold-italic-Ïµsubscriptğ±ğ‘–superscriptsubscriptğ±ğ‘–ğ‘œsubscriptbold-italic-Ïµsubscriptğ±ğ‘–\displaystyle=h_{{\bf R}^{o},{\bf t}^{o}}({\bf X}_{i})+\bm{\epsilon}_{{\bf x}_% {i}}={\bf x}_{i}^{o}+\bm{\epsilon}_{{\bf x}_{i}},= italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_o end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , bold_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_o end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) + bold_italic_Ïµ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_o end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + bold_italic_Ïµ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , (8)
ğ©jsubscriptğ©ğ‘—\displaystyle{\bf p}_{j}bold_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT =ğ©jo+Ïµğ©j,ğªj=ğªjo+Ïµğªj,formulae-sequenceabsentsuperscriptsubscriptğ©ğ‘—ğ‘œsubscriptbold-italic-Ïµsubscriptğ©ğ‘—subscriptğªğ‘—superscriptsubscriptğªğ‘—ğ‘œsubscriptbold-italic-Ïµsubscriptğªğ‘—\displaystyle={\bf p}_{j}^{o}+\bm{\epsilon}_{{\bf p}_{j}},\leavevmode\nobreak% \ \leavevmode\nobreak\ \leavevmode\nobreak\ \leavevmode\nobreak\ \leavevmode% \nobreak\ \leavevmode\nobreak\ {\bf q}_{j}={\bf q}_{j}^{o}+\bm{\epsilon}_{{\bf q% }_{j}},= bold_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_o end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + bold_italic_Ïµ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , bold_q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = bold_q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_o end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + bold_italic_Ïµ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , (9)

where the quantity (â‹…)osuperscriptâ‹…ğ‘œ(\cdot)^{o}( â‹… ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_o end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT denotes the corresponding noise-free counterpart of (â‹…)â‹…(\cdot)( â‹… ), and Ïµğ±isubscriptbold-italic-Ïµsubscriptğ±ğ‘–\bm{\epsilon}_{{\bf x}_{i}}bold_italic_Ïµ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, Ïµğ©jsubscriptbold-italic-Ïµsubscriptğ©ğ‘—\bm{\epsilon}_{{\bf p}_{j}}bold_italic_Ïµ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, and Ïµğªjsubscriptbold-italic-Ïµsubscriptğªğ‘—\bm{\epsilon}_{{\bf q}_{j}}bold_italic_Ïµ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT are measurement noises, which are assumed to be mutually independent and follow a Gaussian distribution ğ’©â¢(0,Ïƒ2â¢ğˆ2)ğ’©0superscriptğœ2subscriptğˆ2\mathcal{N}\left(0,\sigma^{2}{\bf I}_{2}\right)caligraphic_N ( 0 , italic_Ïƒ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ).

Remark 1.

Note that for the line ğ¥jsubscriptğ¥ğ‘—{\bf l}_{j}bold_l start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, we do not directly add a 3D noise vector to ğ¥josuperscriptsubscriptğ¥ğ‘—ğ‘œ{\bf l}_{j}^{o}bold_l start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_o end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Instead, we add a 2D noise to each of its endpoints. Although this modeling is more complicated and harder to handle111With this modeling, the noise for ğ¥jsubscriptğ¥ğ‘—{\bf l}_{j}bold_l start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT becomes ğ©joâ¢hÃ—Ïµğªjh+Ïµğ©jhÃ—ğªjoâ¢h+Ïµğ©jhÃ—Ïµğªjhsuperscriptsubscriptğ©ğ‘—ğ‘œâ„superscriptsubscriptbold-Ïµsubscriptğªğ‘—â„superscriptsubscriptbold-Ïµsubscriptğ©ğ‘—â„superscriptsubscriptğªğ‘—ğ‘œâ„superscriptsubscriptbold-Ïµsubscriptğ©ğ‘—â„superscriptsubscriptbold-Ïµsubscriptğªğ‘—â„{\bf p}_{j}^{oh}\times\bm{\epsilon}_{{\bf q}_{j}}^{h}+\bm{\epsilon}_{{\bf p}_{% j}}^{h}\times{\bf q}_{j}^{oh}+\bm{\epsilon}_{{\bf p}_{j}}^{h}\times\bm{% \epsilon}_{{\bf q}_{j}}^{h}bold_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_o italic_h end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT Ã— bold_italic_Ïµ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_h end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + bold_italic_Ïµ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_h end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT Ã— bold_q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_o italic_h end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + bold_italic_Ïµ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_h end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT Ã— bold_italic_Ïµ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_h end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, which is no longer a Gaussian noise. Here, Ïµğ©jhâ‰œ[Ïµğ©jâŠ¤â¢ 0]âŠ¤â‰œsuperscriptsubscriptbold-Ïµsubscriptğ©ğ‘—â„superscriptdelimited-[]superscriptsubscriptbold-Ïµsubscriptğ©ğ‘—top 0top\bm{\epsilon}_{{\bf p}_{j}}^{h}\triangleq[\bm{\epsilon}_{{\bf p}_{j}}^{\top}% \leavevmode\nobreak\ 0]^{\top}bold_italic_Ïµ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_h end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‰œ [ bold_italic_Ïµ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âŠ¤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 0 ] start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âŠ¤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and Ïµğªjhâ‰œ[ÏµğªjâŠ¤â¢ 0]âŠ¤â‰œsuperscriptsubscriptbold-Ïµsubscriptğªğ‘—â„superscriptdelimited-[]superscriptsubscriptbold-Ïµsubscriptğªğ‘—top 0top\bm{\epsilon}_{{\bf q}_{j}}^{h}\triangleq[\bm{\epsilon}_{{\bf q}_{j}}^{\top}% \leavevmode\nobreak\ 0]^{\top}bold_italic_Ïµ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_h end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‰œ [ bold_italic_Ïµ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âŠ¤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 0 ] start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âŠ¤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT., it is more in line with the fact that the original measurements of a camera are a series of points. This modeling also satisfies the intuition that longer line segments are less affected by the noises on their endpoints, i.e., the longer a line segment is, the more confident we are with the observation. Actually, adding noises to the endpoints of a line is widely used in the simulation of previous worksÂ [29, 26, 30, 7].

Based on the point measurement modelÂ (8), the residual for the iğ‘–iitalic_i-th point is

ğ«pâ¢iâ¢(ğ‘,ğ­)=ğ±iâˆ’hğ‘,ğ­â¢(ğ—i),subscriptğ«ğ‘ğ‘–ğ‘ğ­subscriptğ±ğ‘–subscriptâ„ğ‘ğ­subscriptğ—ğ‘–{\bf r}_{pi}({\bf R},{\bf t})={\bf x}_{i}-h_{{\bf R},{\bf t}}({\bf X}_{i}),bold_r start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_R , bold_t ) = bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_R , bold_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) , (10)

and the weight matrix is ğšºâˆ’1=1Ïƒ2â¢ğˆ2superscriptğšº11superscriptğœ2subscriptğˆ2\bm{\Sigma}^{-1}=\frac{1}{\sigma^{2}}{\bf I}_{2}bold_Î£ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_Ïƒ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG bold_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. However, the residual for the jğ‘—jitalic_j-th line is not so straightforward since the 3D points associated with ğ©jsubscriptğ©ğ‘—{\bf p}_{j}bold_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and ğªjsubscriptğªğ‘—{\bf q}_{j}bold_q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT are unknown. Let ğ¥Â¯jâ‰œ[ğ‘ğ­âˆ§â¢ğ‘]â¢ğ‹jâ‰œsubscriptÂ¯ğ¥ğ‘—ğ‘superscriptğ­ğ‘subscriptğ‹ğ‘—\bar{\bf l}_{j}\triangleq\left[{\bf R}\leavevmode\nobreak\ \leavevmode\nobreak% \ {\bf t}^{\wedge}{\bf R}\right]{\bf L}_{j}overÂ¯ start_ARG bold_l end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‰œ [ bold_R bold_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ§ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_R ] bold_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Note that ğ©josuperscriptsubscriptğ©ğ‘—ğ‘œ{\bf p}_{j}^{o}bold_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_o end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and ğªjosuperscriptsubscriptğªğ‘—ğ‘œ{\bf q}_{j}^{o}bold_q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_o end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT lie on ğ¥Â¯joâ‰œ[ğ‘oğ­oâˆ§â¢ğ‘o]â¢ğ‹jâ‰œsuperscriptsubscriptÂ¯ğ¥ğ‘—ğ‘œsuperscriptğ‘ğ‘œsuperscriptğ­limit-fromğ‘œsuperscriptğ‘ğ‘œsubscriptğ‹ğ‘—\bar{\bf l}_{j}^{o}\triangleq\left[{\bf R}^{o}\leavevmode\nobreak\ \leavevmode% \nobreak\ {\bf t}^{o\wedge}{\bf R}^{o}\right]{\bf L}_{j}overÂ¯ start_ARG bold_l end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_o end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‰œ [ bold_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_o end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_o âˆ§ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_o end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ] bold_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. We have ğ¥Â¯joâŠ¤â¢ğ©joâ¢h=0superscriptsubscriptÂ¯ğ¥ğ‘—limit-fromğ‘œtopsuperscriptsubscriptğ©ğ‘—ğ‘œâ„0\bar{\bf l}_{j}^{o\top}{\bf p}_{j}^{oh}=0overÂ¯ start_ARG bold_l end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_o âŠ¤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_o italic_h end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = 0 and ğ¥Â¯joâŠ¤â¢ğªjoâ¢h=0superscriptsubscriptÂ¯ğ¥ğ‘—limit-fromğ‘œtopsuperscriptsubscriptğªğ‘—ğ‘œâ„0\bar{\bf l}_{j}^{o\top}{\bf q}_{j}^{oh}=0overÂ¯ start_ARG bold_l end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_o âŠ¤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_o italic_h end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = 0, which give

The explicit expression of Ïƒj2â¢(ğ‘o,ğ­o)superscriptsubscriptğœğ‘—2superscriptğ‘ğ‘œsuperscriptğ­ğ‘œ\sigma_{j}^{2}({\bf R}^{o},{\bf t}^{o})italic_Ïƒ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( bold_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_o end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , bold_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_o end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) is Ïƒj2â¢(ğ‘o,ğ­o)=[ğ¥Â¯jo]1:2âŠ¤â¢ğšºâ¢[ğ¥Â¯jo]1:2superscriptsubscriptğœğ‘—2superscriptğ‘ğ‘œsuperscriptğ­ğ‘œsuperscriptsubscriptdelimited-[]superscriptsubscriptÂ¯ğ¥ğ‘—ğ‘œ:12topğšºsubscriptdelimited-[]superscriptsubscriptÂ¯ğ¥ğ‘—ğ‘œ:12\sigma_{j}^{2}({\bf R}^{o},{\bf t}^{o})=[\bar{\bf l}_{j}^{o}]_{1:2}^{\top}{\bm% {\Sigma}}[\bar{\bf l}_{j}^{o}]_{1:2}italic_Ïƒ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( bold_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_o end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , bold_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_o end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) = [ overÂ¯ start_ARG bold_l end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_o end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ] start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 : 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âŠ¤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_Î£ [ overÂ¯ start_ARG bold_l end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_o end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ] start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 : 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, where [ğ¥Â¯jo]1:2subscriptdelimited-[]superscriptsubscriptÂ¯ğ¥ğ‘—ğ‘œ:12[\bar{\bf l}_{j}^{o}]_{1:2}[ overÂ¯ start_ARG bold_l end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_o end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ] start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 : 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT denotes the first two elements of ğ¥Â¯josuperscriptsubscriptÂ¯ğ¥ğ‘—ğ‘œ\bar{\bf l}_{j}^{o}overÂ¯ start_ARG bold_l end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_o end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. As a result, the residual for the jğ‘—jitalic_j-th line is formulated as

ğ«lâ¢jâ¢(ğ‘,ğ­)=[ğ©jhâŠ¤ğªjhâŠ¤]â¢[ğ‘ğ­âˆ§â¢ğ‘]â¢ğ‹j,subscriptğ«ğ‘™ğ‘—ğ‘ğ­matrixsuperscriptsubscriptğ©ğ‘—limit-fromâ„topsuperscriptsubscriptğªğ‘—limit-fromâ„topğ‘superscriptğ­ğ‘subscriptğ‹ğ‘—{\bf r}_{lj}({\bf R},{\bf t})=\begin{bmatrix}{\bf p}_{j}^{h\top}\\ {\bf q}_{j}^{h\top}\end{bmatrix}\left[{\bf R}\leavevmode\nobreak\ \leavevmode% \nobreak\ {\bf t}^{\wedge}{\bf R}\right]{\bf L}_{j},bold_r start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_R , bold_t ) = [ start_ARG start_ROW start_CELL bold_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_h âŠ¤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL bold_q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_h âŠ¤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_CELL end_ROW end_ARG ] [ bold_R bold_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ§ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_R ] bold_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , (12)

and the weight matrix is ğšºjâˆ’1=1Ïƒj2â¢(ğ‘o,ğ­o)â¢ğˆ2superscriptsubscriptğšºğ‘—11superscriptsubscriptğœğ‘—2superscriptğ‘ğ‘œsuperscriptğ­ğ‘œsubscriptğˆ2\bm{\Sigma}_{j}^{-1}=\frac{1}{\sigma_{j}^{2}({\bf R}^{o},{\bf t}^{o})}{\bf I}_% {2}bold_Î£ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_Ïƒ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( bold_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_o end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , bold_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_o end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) end_ARG bold_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.

Finally, by combining the point residualÂ (10) and line residualÂ (12), the ML problem is formulated as

minimizeğ‘,ğ­1n+mâ¢(âˆ‘i=1nâ€–ğ«pâ¢iâ€–ğšº2+âˆ‘j=1mâ€–ğ«lâ¢jâ€–ğšºj2)subjectâ¢toğ‘âˆˆSOâ¢(3),ğ­âˆˆâ„3,formulae-sequencesubscriptminimizeğ‘ğ­1ğ‘›ğ‘šsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ‘›superscriptsubscriptdelimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥subscriptğ«ğ‘ğ‘–ğšº2superscriptsubscriptğ‘—1ğ‘šsuperscriptsubscriptdelimited-âˆ¥âˆ¥subscriptğ«ğ‘™ğ‘—subscriptğšºğ‘—2subjecttoğ‘SO3ğ­superscriptâ„3\begin{split}\mathop{\rm minimize}\limits_{{\bf R},{\bf t}}\leavevmode\nobreak% \ &\frac{1}{n+m}\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n}\left\|{\bf r}_{pi}\right\|_{\bm{\Sigma}}^% {2}+\sum_{j=1}^{m}\left\|{\bf r}_{lj}\right\|_{\bm{\Sigma}_{j}}^{2}\right)\\ \mathop{\rm subject\leavevmode\nobreak\ to}\leavevmode\nobreak\ &{\bf R}\in{% \rm SO}(3),{\bf t}\in\mathbb{R}^{3},\end{split}start_ROW start_CELL roman_minimize start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_R , bold_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_CELL start_CELL divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_n + italic_m end_ARG ( âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ¥ bold_r start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_Î£ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ¥ bold_r start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_Î£ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL roman_subject roman_to end_CELL start_CELL bold_R âˆˆ roman_SO ( 3 ) , bold_t âˆˆ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , end_CELL end_ROW (13)

where we have abbreviated ğ«pâ¢iâ¢(ğ‘,ğ­)subscriptğ«ğ‘ğ‘–ğ‘ğ­{\bf r}_{pi}({\bf R},{\bf t})bold_r start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_R , bold_t ) and ğ«lâ¢jâ¢(ğ‘,ğ­)subscriptğ«ğ‘™ğ‘—ğ‘ğ­{\bf r}_{lj}({\bf R},{\bf t})bold_r start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_R , bold_t ) to ğ«pâ¢isubscriptğ«ğ‘ğ‘–{\bf r}_{pi}bold_r start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and ğ«lâ¢jsubscriptğ«ğ‘™ğ‘—{\bf r}_{lj}bold_r start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, respectively. A global solution toÂ (13) is called an ML estimate, denoted as ğ‘^MLsuperscript^ğ‘ML\hat{\bf R}^{\rm ML}over^ start_ARG bold_R end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_ML end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and ğ­^MLsuperscript^ğ­ML\hat{\bf t}^{\rm ML}over^ start_ARG bold_t end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_ML end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, and an algorithm that optimally solvesÂ (13) is termed an ML estimator. Note that the degrees of ğ‘ğ‘\bf Rbold_R and ğ­ğ­\bf tbold_t are both 3333, and each point or line correspondence can provide 2222 independent equations. Hence, at least n+m=3ğ‘›ğ‘š3n+m=3italic_n + italic_m = 3 point/line correspondences are required to estimate the camera pose.

From the statistical theory, we know that under some regularity conditions, an ML estimate is consistent and asymptotically efficient. Thanks to the development of modern feature extraction techniques, a large number of features can exist in a single image. For example, FigureÂ 2 shows two images from the ETH3DÂ [41] and VGGÂ [42] datasets, respectively. One image contains thousands of point features, and the other has hundreds of line features. The main problem of interest in this paper is to fully exploit the value of large sample features, which can be achieved by optimally solving the ML problemÂ (13).

4 Algorithm framework

The ML problemÂ (13) is nonconvex since the objective is nonconvex, and the SOâ¢(3)SO3{\rm SO}(3)roman_SO ( 3 ) group is not a convex set. In addition, the covariance matrices ğšºğšº\bm{\Sigma}bold_Î£ and ğšºj,j=1,â€¦,mformulae-sequencesubscriptğšºğ‘—ğ‘—1â€¦ğ‘š\bm{\Sigma}_{j},j=1,\ldots,mbold_Î£ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_j = 1 , â€¦ , italic_m are unknown. As a result, a global solution to the ML problem is hard to obtain. When using a locally iterative method to solve the ML problem, e.g., the GN algorithm, it is required that the initial value falls into the attraction neighborhood of a global minimum, otherwise, we can only obtain a locally optimal solution.

In this paper, our focus is to devise an algorithm that can yield an estimate, which owns the same asymptotic properties as the ML estimate. In other words, we are going to propose a consistent and asymptotically efficient estimator. The algorithm framework is shown in FigureÂ 3. The input of our algorithm includes the camera intrinsic matrix ğŠğŠ\bf Kbold_K, nğ‘›nitalic_n point correspondences, and mğ‘šmitalic_m line correspondences, where all 2D points are expressed as pixel coordinates (â‹…)pxsuperscriptâ‹…px(\cdot)^{\rm px}( â‹… ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_px end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. The output is the estimate of the camera pose. Our algorithm consists of four components. In what follows, we will outline their functions respectively.

(1) Preprocessing. By drawing lessons from the existing literatureÂ [21, 29], points and lines need to be normalized to make an algorithm numerically stable. In practice, the main principle is that points and lines with large absolute values need to be normalized. For the detected 2D points, we convert their pixel coordinates into normalized image coordinates based on the cameraâ€™s intrinsic parameters. Take ğ±ipxsuperscriptsubscriptğ±ğ‘–px{\bf x}_{i}^{\rm px}bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_px end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT as example, and we have

ğ±i=[ğŠâˆ’1]1:2â¢[ğ±ipx1],subscriptğ±ğ‘–subscriptdelimited-[]superscriptğŠ1:12matrixsuperscriptsubscriptğ±ğ‘–px1{\bf x}_{i}=[{\bf K}^{-1}]_{1:2}\begin{bmatrix}{\bf x}_{i}^{\rm px}\\ 1\end{bmatrix},bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = [ bold_K start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ] start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 : 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ start_ARG start_ROW start_CELL bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_px end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL 1 end_CELL end_ROW end_ARG ] ,

where [ğŠâˆ’1]1:2subscriptdelimited-[]superscriptğŠ1:12[{\bf K}^{-1}]_{1:2}[ bold_K start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ] start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 : 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT denotes the first two rows of ğŠâˆ’1superscriptğŠ1{\bf K}^{-1}bold_K start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. The line endpoints ğ©jsubscriptğ©ğ‘—{\bf p}_{j}bold_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and ğªjsubscriptğªğ‘—{\bf q}_{j}bold_q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT can be obtained in the same way. For each 3D line ğ‹jsubscriptğ‹ğ‘—{\bf L}_{j}bold_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, we move ğjsubscriptğğ‘—{\bf P}_{j}bold_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and ğjsubscriptğğ‘—{\bf Q}_{j}bold_Q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT along the line direction such that â€–ğjâˆ’ğjâ€–=3normsubscriptğğ‘—subscriptğğ‘—3\|{\bf P}_{j}-{\bf Q}_{j}\|=\sqrt{3}âˆ¥ bold_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - bold_Q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¥ = square-root start_ARG 3 end_ARG.

(2) Noise variance estimation. For a nonlinear and nonconvex optimization problem, solutions obtained by some relaxation-based methods are usually biased, and the bias is generally associated with the variance of measurement noises. Therefore, it is important to estimate noise variance in order to eliminate the bias, obtaining an asymptotically unbiased and consistent solution. The technical details of noise variance estimation will be presented in SectionÂ 5. The resulting consistent noise variance estimate will be utilized in the components of consistent estimate generation and GN iterations.

(3) Consistent estimate generation. We relax the original ML problemÂ (13) to a generalized trust region subproblem (GTRS) whose global solution can be obtained. In addition, based on the noise variance estimate, we conduct bias elimination, which yields a consistent pose estimate. The consistent estimate serves as a good initial value for the following GN iterations to find the ML estimate. In addition, the consistent estimator has a closed-form expression and thus is computationally efficient. The technical details of consistent estimate generation will be presented in SectionÂ 5.

(4) Gauss-Newton iterations. Taking the consistent estimate as the initial value, the GN algorithm is executed to find the ML estimate. With the increase of the measurement number, the consistent estimate can converge into the attraction neighborhood of the global minimum of the ML problemÂ (13), hence the ML estimate is achievable in the large sample case. It is worth noting that due to the SO(3) constraint on the rotation matrix and ğšºjsubscriptğšºğ‘—{\bm{\Sigma}}_{j}bold_Î£ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT inÂ (13) being a function of the true pose, a modified GN algorithm instead of the standard one needs to be designed. The proposed GN iterations and the resulting asymptotic efficiency will be presented in SectionÂ 6 in detail.

5 Consistent estimator design

In this section, we will detail the initial consistent estimator in the first step. SubsectionÂ 5.1 is for the case of point features, SubsectionÂ 5.2 is for the case of line features, and the case of combined point and line features is described in SubsectionÂ 5.3.

5.1 Consistent estimation from point correspondences

Since ğ±ioâ¢hsuperscriptsubscriptğ±ğ‘–ğ‘œâ„{\bf x}_{i}^{oh}bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_o italic_h end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is parallel to ğ‘oâ¢ğ—i+ğ­osuperscriptğ‘ğ‘œsubscriptğ—ğ‘–superscriptğ­ğ‘œ{\bf R}^{o}{\bf X}_{i}+{\bf t}^{o}bold_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_o end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + bold_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_o end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT (see FigureÂ 1 for geometric illustration), we have ğ±ioâ¢hÃ—(ğ‘oâ¢ğ—i+ğ­o)=0superscriptsubscriptğ±ğ‘–ğ‘œâ„superscriptğ‘ğ‘œsubscriptğ—ğ‘–superscriptğ­ğ‘œ0{\bf x}_{i}^{oh}\times({\bf R}^{o}{\bf X}_{i}+{\bf t}^{o})=0bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_o italic_h end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT Ã— ( bold_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_o end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + bold_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_o end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) = 0, i.e.,

0=ğ±ihÃ—(ğ‘oâ¢ğ—i+ğ­o)âˆ’ğœºğ±i,0superscriptsubscriptğ±ğ‘–â„superscriptğ‘ğ‘œsubscriptğ—ğ‘–superscriptğ­ğ‘œsubscriptğœºsubscriptğ±ğ‘–0={\bf x}_{i}^{h}\times({\bf R}^{o}{\bf X}_{i}+{\bf t}^{o})-\bm{\varepsilon}_{% {\bf x}_{i}},0 = bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_h end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT Ã— ( bold_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_o end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + bold_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_o end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) - bold_italic_Îµ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , (14)

where ğœºğ±i=Ïµğ±ihÃ—(ğ‘oâ¢ğ—i+ğ­o)subscriptğœºsubscriptğ±ğ‘–superscriptsubscriptbold-italic-Ïµsubscriptğ±ğ‘–â„superscriptğ‘ğ‘œsubscriptğ—ğ‘–superscriptğ­ğ‘œ\bm{\varepsilon}_{{\bf x}_{i}}=\bm{\epsilon}_{{\bf x}_{i}}^{h}\times({\bf R}^{% o}{\bf X}_{i}+{\bf t}^{o})bold_italic_Îµ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = bold_italic_Ïµ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_h end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT Ã— ( bold_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_o end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + bold_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_o end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ). Define ğœ½oâ‰œvecâ¢([ğ‘oâ¢ğ­o])â‰œsuperscriptğœ½ğ‘œvecdelimited-[]superscriptğ‘ğ‘œsuperscriptğ­ğ‘œ{\bm{\theta}}^{o}\triangleq{\rm vec}([{\bf R}^{o}\leavevmode\nobreak\ {\bf t}^% {o}])bold_italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_o end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‰œ roman_vec ( [ bold_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_o end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_o end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ] ) and ğ—Â¯i=ğ—iâŠ¤âŠ—ğˆ3subscriptÂ¯ğ—ğ‘–tensor-productsuperscriptsubscriptğ—ğ‘–topsubscriptğˆ3\mkern 2.5mu\overline{\mkern-2.5mu\bf X\mkern-2.5mu}\mkern 2.5mu_{i}={\bf X}_{% i}^{\top}\otimes{\bf I}_{3}overÂ¯ start_ARG bold_X end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = bold_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âŠ¤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âŠ— bold_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Then, equationÂ (14) can be converted to

0=[ğ±ihâˆ§â¢ğ—Â¯iğ±ihâˆ§]â¢ğœ½oâˆ’ğœºğ±i.0superscriptsubscriptğ±ğ‘–limit-fromâ„subscriptÂ¯ğ—ğ‘–superscriptsubscriptğ±ğ‘–limit-fromâ„superscriptğœ½ğ‘œsubscriptğœºsubscriptğ±ğ‘–0=\left[{\bf x}_{i}^{h\wedge}\mkern 2.5mu\overline{\mkern-2.5mu\bf X\mkern-2.5% mu}\mkern 2.5mu_{i}\leavevmode\nobreak\ \leavevmode\nobreak\ {\bf x}_{i}^{h% \wedge}\right]{\bm{\theta}}^{o}-\bm{\varepsilon}_{{\bf x}_{i}}.0 = [ bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_h âˆ§ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT overÂ¯ start_ARG bold_X end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_h âˆ§ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ] bold_italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_o end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - bold_italic_Îµ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT . (15)

EquationÂ (15) only has two independent scalar equations due to the fact that ğ±isubscriptğ±ğ‘–{\bf x}_{i}bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT has two degrees of freedomÂ [21, 29]. Hence, we select the first two rows ofÂ (15) and stack them for nğ‘›nitalic_n point correspondences, obtaining the matrix form

0=ğ€nâ¢ğœ½oâˆ’ğœºğ±,0subscriptğ€ğ‘›superscriptğœ½ğ‘œsubscriptğœºğ±0={\bf A}_{n}{\bm{\theta}}^{o}-\bm{\varepsilon}_{{\bf x}},0 = bold_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_italic_Î¸ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_o end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - bold_italic_Îµ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , (16)

where
