and ğ~nâ¢mâ¢1â‰œğ€~nâ¢mâ¢1âŠ¤â¢ğ€~nâ¢mâ¢1/(n+m)â‰œsubscript~ğğ‘›ğ‘š1superscriptsubscript~ğ€ğ‘›ğ‘š1topsubscript~ğ€ğ‘›ğ‘š1ğ‘›ğ‘š\tilde{\bf Q}_{nm1}\triangleq\tilde{\bf A}_{nm1}^{\top}\tilde{\bf A}_{nm1}/(n+m)over~ start_ARG bold_Q end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n italic_m 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‰œ over~ start_ARG bold_A end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n italic_m 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âŠ¤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT over~ start_ARG bold_A end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n italic_m 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT / ( italic_n + italic_m ), ğ~nâ¢mâ¢2â‰œğ€~nâ¢mâ¢2âŠ¤â¢ğ€~nâ¢mâ¢2/(n+m)â‰œsubscript~ğğ‘›ğ‘š2superscriptsubscript~ğ€ğ‘›ğ‘š2topsubscript~ğ€ğ‘›ğ‘š2ğ‘›ğ‘š\tilde{\bf Q}_{nm2}\triangleq\tilde{\bf A}_{nm2}^{\top}\tilde{\bf A}_{nm2}/(n+m)over~ start_ARG bold_Q end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n italic_m 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‰œ over~ start_ARG bold_A end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n italic_m 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âŠ¤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT over~ start_ARG bold_A end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n italic_m 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT / ( italic_n + italic_m ), and ğ~nâ¢mâ¢3â‰œğ€~nâ¢mâ¢3âŠ¤â¢ğ€~nâ¢mâ¢3/(n+m)â‰œsubscript~ğğ‘›ğ‘š3superscriptsubscript~ğ€ğ‘›ğ‘š3topsubscript~ğ€ğ‘›ğ‘š3ğ‘›ğ‘š\tilde{\bf Q}_{nm3}\triangleq\tilde{\bf A}_{nm3}^{\top}\tilde{\bf A}_{nm3}/(n+m)over~ start_ARG bold_Q end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n italic_m 3 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‰œ over~ start_ARG bold_A end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n italic_m 3 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âŠ¤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT over~ start_ARG bold_A end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n italic_m 3 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT / ( italic_n + italic_m ). Then, the following theorem is a direct corollary of TheoremsÂ 1 andÂ 3:

Theorem 5.

Suppose Ïƒ^nâ¢m2subscriptsuperscript^ğœ2ğ‘›ğ‘š\hat{\sigma}^{2}_{nm}over^ start_ARG italic_Ïƒ end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is a n+mğ‘›ğ‘š\sqrt{n+m}square-root start_ARG italic_n + italic_m end_ARG-consistent estimate of the measurement noise variance Ïƒ2superscriptğœ2\sigma^{2}italic_Ïƒ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Let ğnâ¢mBEâ‰œğnâ¢mâˆ’Ïƒ^nâ¢m2â¢(ğ~nâ¢mâ¢1+ğ~nâ¢mâ¢2+ğ~nâ¢mâ¢3)â‰œsuperscriptsubscriptğğ‘›ğ‘šBEsubscriptğğ‘›ğ‘šsubscriptsuperscript^ğœ2ğ‘›ğ‘šsubscript~ğğ‘›ğ‘š1subscript~ğğ‘›ğ‘š2subscript~ğğ‘›ğ‘š3{\bf Q}_{nm}^{\rm BE}\triangleq{\bf Q}_{nm}-\hat{\sigma}^{2}_{nm}(\tilde{\bf Q% }_{nm1}+\tilde{\bf Q}_{nm2}+\tilde{\bf Q}_{nm3})bold_Q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_BE end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‰œ bold_Q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - over^ start_ARG italic_Ïƒ end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( over~ start_ARG bold_Q end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n italic_m 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + over~ start_ARG bold_Q end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n italic_m 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + over~ start_ARG bold_Q end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n italic_m 3 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ). Then,

ğnâ¢mBE=ğnâ¢mo+Opâ¢(1/n+m).superscriptsubscriptğğ‘›ğ‘šBEsuperscriptsubscriptğğ‘›ğ‘šğ‘œsubscriptğ‘‚ğ‘1ğ‘›ğ‘š{\bf Q}_{nm}^{\rm BE}={\bf Q}_{nm}^{o}+O_{p}(1/\sqrt{n+m}).bold_Q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_BE end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = bold_Q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_o end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + italic_O start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( 1 / square-root start_ARG italic_n + italic_m end_ARG ) . (25)

Moreover, any unit eigenvector corresponding to the smallest eigenvalue of ğnâ¢mBEsuperscriptsubscriptğğ‘›ğ‘šBE{\bf Q}_{nm}^{\rm BE}bold_Q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_BE end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, denoted as ğ›‰^nâ¢mBEsubscriptsuperscript^ğ›‰BEğ‘›ğ‘š\hat{\bm{\theta}}^{\rm BE}_{nm}over^ start_ARG bold_italic_Î¸ end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_BE end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, is a n+mğ‘›ğ‘š\sqrt{n+m}square-root start_ARG italic_n + italic_m end_ARG-consistent estimate of ğ›‰Â¯osuperscriptÂ¯ğ›‰ğ‘œ\bar{\bm{\theta}}^{o}overÂ¯ start_ARG bold_italic_Î¸ end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_o end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT up to sign.

Corollary 3.

The estimate ğ›‰^nâ¢mBEsubscriptsuperscript^ğ›‰BEğ‘›ğ‘š\hat{\bm{\theta}}^{\rm BE}_{nm}over^ start_ARG bold_italic_Î¸ end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_BE end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is an asymptotically unbiased estimate of ğ›‰Â¯osuperscriptÂ¯ğ›‰ğ‘œ\bar{\bm{\theta}}^{o}overÂ¯ start_ARG bold_italic_Î¸ end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_o end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT up to sign.

The following theorem gives a n+mğ‘›ğ‘š\sqrt{n+m}square-root start_ARG italic_n + italic_m end_ARG-consistent estimate of noise variance from combined point and line correspondences:

Theorem 6.

Let Ïƒ^nâ¢m2â‰œ1/Î»maxâ¢(ğnâ¢mâˆ’1â¢(ğ~nâ¢mâ¢1+ğ~nâ¢mâ¢2+ğ~nâ¢mâ¢3))â‰œsubscriptsuperscript^ğœ2ğ‘›ğ‘š1subscriptğœ†maxsuperscriptsubscriptğğ‘›ğ‘š1subscript~ğğ‘›ğ‘š1subscript~ğğ‘›ğ‘š2subscript~ğğ‘›ğ‘š3\hat{\sigma}^{2}_{nm}\triangleq 1/\lambda_{\rm max}({\bf Q}_{nm}^{-1}(\tilde{% \bf Q}_{nm1}+\tilde{\bf Q}_{nm2}+\tilde{\bf Q}_{nm3}))over^ start_ARG italic_Ïƒ end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‰œ 1 / italic_Î» start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_max end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_Q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( over~ start_ARG bold_Q end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n italic_m 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + over~ start_ARG bold_Q end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n italic_m 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + over~ start_ARG bold_Q end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n italic_m 3 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ). Then, Ïƒ^nâ¢m2âˆ’Ïƒ2=Opâ¢(1/n+m)subscriptsuperscript^ğœ2ğ‘›ğ‘šsuperscriptğœ2subscriptğ‘‚ğ‘1ğ‘›ğ‘š\hat{\sigma}^{2}_{nm}-\sigma^{2}=O_{p}(1/\sqrt{n+m})over^ start_ARG italic_Ïƒ end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_Ïƒ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = italic_O start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( 1 / square-root start_ARG italic_n + italic_m end_ARG ), i.e., Ïƒ^nâ¢m2subscriptsuperscript^ğœ2ğ‘›ğ‘š\hat{\sigma}^{2}_{nm}over^ start_ARG italic_Ïƒ end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is a n+mğ‘›ğ‘š\sqrt{n+m}square-root start_ARG italic_n + italic_m end_ARG-consistent estimate of Ïƒ2superscriptğœ2\sigma^{2}italic_Ïƒ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT.

The proof of TheoremÂ 6 is similar to that of TheoremÂ 2 and is omitted here. Note that ğnâ¢mâˆˆâ„21Ã—21subscriptğğ‘›ğ‘šsuperscriptâ„2121{\bf Q}_{nm}\in\mathbb{R}^{21\times 21}bold_Q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆˆ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 21 Ã— 21 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT should be invertible. Hence, we require that n+mâ‰¥11ğ‘›ğ‘š11n+m\geq 11italic_n + italic_m â‰¥ 11, which is stricter than the condition n+mâ‰¥10ğ‘›ğ‘š10n+m\geq 10italic_n + italic_m â‰¥ 10 for only solving problemÂ (24).

The procedure to recover pose [ğ‘^nâ¢mBEğ­^nâ¢mBE]subscriptsuperscript^ğ‘BEğ‘›ğ‘šsubscriptsuperscript^ğ­BEğ‘›ğ‘š[\hat{\bf R}^{\rm BE}_{nm}\leavevmode\nobreak\ \leavevmode\nobreak\ \hat{\bf t% }^{\rm BE}_{nm}][ over^ start_ARG bold_R end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_BE end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT over^ start_ARG bold_t end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_BE end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] from ğœ½^nâ¢mBEâˆˆâ„21subscriptsuperscript^ğœ½BEğ‘›ğ‘šsuperscriptâ„21\hat{\bm{\theta}}^{\rm BE}_{nm}\in\mathbb{R}^{21}over^ start_ARG bold_italic_Î¸ end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_BE end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆˆ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 21 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is presented in AlgorithmÂ 5. Coinciding with AlgorithmÂ 4, the rotation matrix ğ‘^nâ¢mBEsubscriptsuperscript^ğ‘BEğ‘›ğ‘š\hat{\bf R}^{\rm BE}_{nm}over^ start_ARG bold_R end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_BE end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is only retrieved from [ğœ½^nâ¢mBE]1:9subscriptdelimited-[]subscriptsuperscript^ğœ½BEğ‘›ğ‘š:19[\hat{\bm{\theta}}^{\rm BE}_{nm}]_{1:9}[ over^ start_ARG bold_italic_Î¸ end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_BE end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 : 9 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. While note that both [ğœ½^nâ¢mBE]10:18subscriptdelimited-[]subscriptsuperscript^ğœ½BEğ‘›ğ‘š:1018[\hat{\bm{\theta}}^{\rm BE}_{nm}]_{10:18}[ over^ start_ARG bold_italic_Î¸ end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_BE end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 10 : 18 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and [ğœ½^nâ¢mBE]19:21subscriptdelimited-[]subscriptsuperscript^ğœ½BEğ‘›ğ‘š:1921[\hat{\bm{\theta}}^{\rm BE}_{nm}]_{19:21}[ over^ start_ARG bold_italic_Î¸ end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_BE end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 19 : 21 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT are scaled by sğ‘ sitalic_s and have comparable accuracy. Hence, the translation vector ğ­^nâ¢mBEsubscriptsuperscript^ğ­BEğ‘›ğ‘š\hat{\bf t}^{\rm BE}_{nm}over^ start_ARG bold_t end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_BE end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is obtained by fusing the information of [ğœ½^nâ¢mBE]10:18subscriptdelimited-[]subscriptsuperscript^ğœ½BEğ‘›ğ‘š:1018[\hat{\bm{\theta}}^{\rm BE}_{nm}]_{10:18}[ over^ start_ARG bold_italic_Î¸ end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_BE end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 10 : 18 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and [ğœ½^nâ¢mBE]19:21subscriptdelimited-[]subscriptsuperscript^ğœ½BEğ‘›ğ‘š:1921[\hat{\bm{\theta}}^{\rm BE}_{nm}]_{19:21}[ over^ start_ARG bold_italic_Î¸ end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_BE end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 19 : 21 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Note that ğœ½^nâ¢mBEsubscriptsuperscript^ğœ½BEğ‘›ğ‘š\hat{\bm{\theta}}^{\rm BE}_{nm}over^ start_ARG bold_italic_Î¸ end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_BE end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is a n+mğ‘›ğ‘š\sqrt{n+m}square-root start_ARG italic_n + italic_m end_ARG-consistent and asymptotically unbiased estimate of ğœ½Â¯osuperscriptÂ¯ğœ½ğ‘œ\bar{\bm{\theta}}^{o}overÂ¯ start_ARG bold_italic_Î¸ end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_o end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT up to sign, and the operations in AlgorithmÂ 5 are all continuous. The retrieved pose [ğ‘^nâ¢mBEğ­^nâ¢mBE]subscriptsuperscript^ğ‘BEğ‘›ğ‘šsubscriptsuperscript^ğ­BEğ‘›ğ‘š[\hat{\bf R}^{\rm BE}_{nm}\leavevmode\nobreak\ \leavevmode\nobreak\ \hat{\bf t% }^{\rm BE}_{nm}][ over^ start_ARG bold_R end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_BE end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT over^ start_ARG bold_t end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_BE end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] is a n+mğ‘›ğ‘š\sqrt{n+m}square-root start_ARG italic_n + italic_m end_ARG-consistent and asymptotically unbiased estimate of [ğ‘oğ­o]superscriptğ‘ğ‘œsuperscriptğ­ğ‘œ[{\bf R}^{o}\leavevmode\nobreak\ \leavevmode\nobreak\ {\bf t}^{o}][ bold_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_o end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_o end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ].

At the end of this section, we conclude our consistent estimator: (1). If nâ‰¥2ğ‘›2n\geq 2italic_n â‰¥ 2, mâ‰¥5ğ‘š5m\geq 5italic_m â‰¥ 5, and n+mâ‰¥11ğ‘›ğ‘š11n+m\geq 11italic_n + italic_m â‰¥ 11, we use both point and line correspondences. First, ğnâ¢msubscriptğğ‘›ğ‘š{\bf Q}_{nm}bold_Q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, ğ~nâ¢mâ¢1subscript~ğğ‘›ğ‘š1\tilde{\bf Q}_{nm1}over~ start_ARG bold_Q end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n italic_m 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, ğ~nâ¢mâ¢2subscript~ğğ‘›ğ‘š2\tilde{\bf Q}_{nm2}over~ start_ARG bold_Q end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n italic_m 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, and ğ~nâ¢mâ¢3subscript~ğğ‘›ğ‘š3\tilde{\bf Q}_{nm3}over~ start_ARG bold_Q end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n italic_m 3 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT are constructed. Then, Ïƒ^nâ¢m2subscriptsuperscript^ğœ2ğ‘›ğ‘š\hat{\sigma}^{2}_{nm}over^ start_ARG italic_Ïƒ end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is calculated according to TheoremÂ 6, based on which the bias-eliminated matrix ğ^nâ¢mBEsuperscriptsubscript^ğğ‘›ğ‘šBE\hat{\bf Q}_{nm}^{\rm BE}over^ start_ARG bold_Q end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_BE end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and solution ğœ½^nâ¢mBEâˆˆâ„21superscriptsubscript^ğœ½ğ‘›ğ‘šBEsuperscriptâ„21\hat{\bm{\theta}}_{nm}^{\rm BE}\in\mathbb{R}^{21}over^ start_ARG bold_italic_Î¸ end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_BE end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆˆ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 21 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT are obtained as shown in TheoremÂ 5. Finally, the consistent pose estimate [ğ‘^nâ¢mBEâ¢ğ­^nâ¢mBE]delimited-[]subscriptsuperscript^ğ‘BEğ‘›ğ‘šsubscriptsuperscript^ğ­BEğ‘›ğ‘š[\hat{\bf R}^{\rm BE}_{nm}\leavevmode\nobreak\ \hat{\bf t}^{\rm BE}_{nm}][ over^ start_ARG bold_R end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_BE end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT over^ start_ARG bold_t end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_BE end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] is recovered in virtue of AlgorithmÂ 5; (2). If nâ‰¥6ğ‘›6n\geq 6italic_n â‰¥ 6 and m<5ğ‘š5m<5italic_m < 5, we only use point correspondences. First, ğnsubscriptğğ‘›{\bf Q}_{n}bold_Q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and ğ~nsubscript~ğğ‘›\tilde{\bf Q}_{n}over~ start_ARG bold_Q end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT are constructed. Then, Ïƒ^n2subscriptsuperscript^ğœ2ğ‘›\hat{\sigma}^{2}_{n}over^ start_ARG italic_Ïƒ end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is calculated according to TheoremÂ 2, based on which the bias-eliminated matrix ğ^nBEsuperscriptsubscript^ğğ‘›BE\hat{\bf Q}_{n}^{\rm BE}over^ start_ARG bold_Q end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_BE end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and solution ğœ½^nBEâˆˆâ„12superscriptsubscript^ğœ½ğ‘›BEsuperscriptâ„12\hat{\bm{\theta}}_{n}^{\rm BE}\in\mathbb{R}^{12}over^ start_ARG bold_italic_Î¸ end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_BE end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆˆ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 12 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT are obtained as shown in TheoremÂ 1. Finally, the consistent pose estimate [ğ‘^nBEâ¢ğ­^nBE]delimited-[]subscriptsuperscript^ğ‘BEğ‘›subscriptsuperscript^ğ­BEğ‘›[\hat{\bf R}^{\rm BE}_{n}\leavevmode\nobreak\ \hat{\bf t}^{\rm BE}_{n}][ over^ start_ARG bold_R end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_BE end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT over^ start_ARG bold_t end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_BE end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] is recovered in virtue of AlgorithmÂ 2; (3). If mâ‰¥9ğ‘š9m\geq 9italic_m â‰¥ 9 and n<2ğ‘›2n<2italic_n < 2, we only use line correspondences. First, ğmsubscriptğğ‘š{\bf Q}_{m}bold_Q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, ğ~mâ¢1subscript~ğğ‘š1\tilde{\bf Q}_{m1}over~ start_ARG bold_Q end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, and ğ~mâ¢2subscript~ğğ‘š2\tilde{\bf Q}_{m2}over~ start_ARG bold_Q end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT are constructed. Then, Ïƒ^m2subscriptsuperscript^ğœ2ğ‘š\hat{\sigma}^{2}_{m}over^ start_ARG italic_Ïƒ end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is calculated according to TheoremÂ 4, based on which the bias-eliminated matrix ğ^mBEsuperscriptsubscript^ğğ‘šBE\hat{\bf Q}_{m}^{\rm BE}over^ start_ARG bold_Q end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_BE end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and solution ğœ½^mBEâˆˆâ„18superscriptsubscript^ğœ½ğ‘šBEsuperscriptâ„18\hat{\bm{\theta}}_{m}^{\rm BE}\in\mathbb{R}^{18}over^ start_ARG bold_italic_Î¸ end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_BE end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆˆ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 18 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT are obtained as shown in TheoremÂ 3. Finally, the consistent pose estimate [ğ‘^mBEâ¢ğ­^mBE]delimited-[]subscriptsuperscript^ğ‘BEğ‘šsubscriptsuperscript^ğ­BEğ‘š[\hat{\bf R}^{\rm BE}_{m}\leavevmode\nobreak\ \hat{\bf t}^{\rm BE}_{m}][ over^ start_ARG bold_R end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_BE end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT over^ start_ARG bold_t end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_BE end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] is recovered in virtue of AlgorithmÂ 4; (4). If n<6ğ‘›6n<6italic_n < 6, m<9ğ‘š9m<9italic_m < 9, and n+m<11ğ‘›ğ‘š11n+m<11italic_n + italic_m < 11, then, the pose is underdetermined in the context of the proposed estimator and cannot be correctly estimated.

For the sake of brevity and unity, in the rest of this paper, we will omit the subscript and uniformly denote the consistent pose estimate as [ğ‘^BEâ¢ğ­^BE]delimited-[]superscript^ğ‘BEsuperscript^ğ­BE[\hat{\bf R}^{\rm BE}\leavevmode\nobreak\ \hat{\bf t}^{\rm BE}][ over^ start_ARG bold_R end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_BE end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT over^ start_ARG bold_t end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_BE end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ] and the consistent noise variance estimate as Ïƒ^2superscript^ğœ2\hat{\sigma}^{2}over^ start_ARG italic_Ïƒ end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT.

6 Asymptotically efficient solution

In the previous section, we have proposed a consistent estimate [ğ‘^BEâ¢ğ­^BE]delimited-[]superscript^ğ‘BEsuperscript^ğ­BE[\hat{\bf R}^{\rm BE}\leavevmode\nobreak\ \hat{\bf t}^{\rm BE}][ over^ start_ARG bold_R end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_BE end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT over^ start_ARG bold_t end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_BE end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ] that converges to the true pose as the measurement number n+mğ‘›ğ‘šn+mitalic_n + italic_m increases. It is noteworthy that although [ğ‘^BEâ¢ğ­^BE]delimited-[]superscript^ğ‘BEsuperscript^ğ­BE[\hat{\bf R}^{\rm BE}\leavevmode\nobreak\ \hat{\bf t}^{\rm BE}][ over^ start_ARG bold_R end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_BE end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT over^ start_ARG bold_t end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_BE end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ] is consistent, it is not asymptotically efficient in the sense that its covariance cannot asymptotically reach the theoretical lower bound CRB. This is because till now, we have just solved a problem relaxed from the ML problemÂ (13), which is not equivalent toÂ (13). In this section, we take [ğ‘^BEâ¢ğ­^BE]delimited-[]superscript^ğ‘BEsuperscript^ğ­BE[\hat{\bf R}^{\rm BE}\leavevmode\nobreak\ \hat{\bf t}^{\rm BE}][ over^ start_ARG bold_R end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_BE end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT over^ start_ARG bold_t end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_BE end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ] as the initial value and perform the GN algorithm to refine it. After that, we can obtain an asymptotically efficient solution.

Recall that the ML estimate [ğ‘^MLâ¢ğ­^ML]delimited-[]superscript^ğ‘MLsuperscript^ğ­ML[\hat{\bf R}^{\rm ML}\leavevmode\nobreak\ \hat{\bf t}^{\rm ML}][ over^ start_ARG bold_R end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_ML end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT over^ start_ARG bold_t end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_ML end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ] is also consistent. Hence, [ğ‘^BEâ¢ğ­^BE]delimited-[]superscript^ğ‘BEsuperscript^ğ­BE[\hat{\bf R}^{\rm BE}\leavevmode\nobreak\ \hat{\bf t}^{\rm BE}][ over^ start_ARG bold_R end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_BE end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT over^ start_ARG bold_t end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_BE end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ] converges to [ğ‘^MLâ¢ğ­^ML]delimited-[]superscript^ğ‘MLsuperscript^ğ­ML[\hat{\bf R}^{\rm ML}\leavevmode\nobreak\ \hat{\bf t}^{\rm ML}][ over^ start_ARG bold_R end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_ML end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT over^ start_ARG bold_t end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_ML end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ] with the increase of n+mğ‘›ğ‘šn+mitalic_n + italic_m. As a result, when n+mğ‘›ğ‘šn+mitalic_n + italic_m is large enough, [ğ‘^BEâ¢ğ­^BE]delimited-[]superscript^ğ‘BEsuperscript^ğ­BE[\hat{\bf R}^{\rm BE}\leavevmode\nobreak\ \hat{\bf t}^{\rm BE}][ over^ start_ARG bold_R end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_BE end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT over^ start_ARG bold_t end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_BE end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ] will fall into the attraction neighborhood of [ğ‘^MLâ¢ğ­^ML]delimited-[]superscript^ğ‘MLsuperscript^ğ­ML[\hat{\bf R}^{\rm ML}\leavevmode\nobreak\ \hat{\bf t}^{\rm ML}][ over^ start_ARG bold_R end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_ML end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT over^ start_ARG bold_t end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_ML end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ], and local iteration methods, e.g., the GN algorithm can find [ğ‘^MLâ¢ğ­^ML]delimited-[]superscript^ğ‘MLsuperscript^ğ­ML[\hat{\bf R}^{\rm ML}\leavevmode\nobreak\ \hat{\bf t}^{\rm ML}][ over^ start_ARG bold_R end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_ML end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT over^ start_ARG bold_t end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_ML end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ] rather than a local minimum. In addition, the GN algorithm can be viewed as an approximation of Newtonâ€™s method. In the large sample case where [ğ‘^BEâ¢ğ­^BE]delimited-[]superscript^ğ‘BEsuperscript^ğ­BE[\hat{\bf R}^{\rm BE}\leavevmode\nobreak\ \hat{\bf t}^{\rm BE}][ over^ start_ARG bold_R end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_BE end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT over^ start_ARG bold_t end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_BE end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ] is sufficiently close to [ğ‘^MLâ¢ğ­^ML]delimited-[]superscript^ğ‘MLsuperscript^ğ­ML[\hat{\bf R}^{\rm ML}\leavevmode\nobreak\ \hat{\bf t}^{\rm ML}][ over^ start_ARG bold_R end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_ML end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT over^ start_ARG bold_t end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_ML end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ], its convergence rate can approach quadratic as the Newtonâ€™s methodÂ [48]. Thanks to the quadratic convergence rate, we show that a single GN iteration is enough to attain the same asymptotic property as the ML estimate, see TheoremÂ 7. Before giving the theorem, we derive the explicit formula of the one-step GN iteration. There are two issues that need to be elaborately solved: First, the weight matrices ğšºjsubscriptğšºğ‘—{\bm{\Sigma}}_{j}bold_Î£ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPTâ€™s in the ML problemÂ (13) depend on the unknown true pose; Second, the rotation matrix needs to meet the SOâ¢(3)SO3{\rm SO}(3)roman_SO ( 3 ) constraint.

As illustrated in SectionÂ 2.4, to satisfy the SOâ¢(3)SO3{\rm SO}(3)roman_SO ( 3 ) constraint, we can use the lifting technique inÂ (4). Specifically, the residual for the iğ‘–iitalic_i-th point correspondence is reparameterized as

ğ«pâ¢iâ¢(ğ¬,ğ­)=ğ±iâˆ’ğ„â¢(ğ‘^BEâ¢expâ¢(ğ¬âˆ§)â¢ğ—i+ğ­)ğ3âŠ¤â¢(ğ‘^BEâ¢expâ¢(ğ¬âˆ§)â¢ğ—i+ğ­),subscriptğ«ğ‘ğ‘–ğ¬ğ­subscriptğ±ğ‘–ğ„superscript^ğ‘BEexpsuperscriptğ¬subscriptğ—ğ‘–ğ­superscriptsubscriptğ3topsuperscript^ğ‘BEexpsuperscriptğ¬subscriptğ—ğ‘–ğ­{\bf r}_{pi}({\bf s},{\bf t})={\bf x}_{i}-\frac{{\bf E}(\hat{\bf R}^{\rm BE}{% \rm exp}({\bf s}^{\wedge}){\bf X}_{i}+{\bf t})}{{\bf e}_{3}^{\top}(\hat{\bf R}% ^{\rm BE}{\rm exp}({\bf s}^{\wedge}){\bf X}_{i}+{\bf t})},bold_r start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_s , bold_t ) = bold_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - divide start_ARG bold_E ( over^ start_ARG bold_R end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_BE end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_exp ( bold_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ§ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) bold_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + bold_t ) end_ARG start_ARG bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âŠ¤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( over^ start_ARG bold_R end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_BE end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_exp ( bold_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ§ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) bold_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + bold_t ) end_ARG ,

where ğ¬âˆˆâ„3ğ¬superscriptâ„3{\bf s}\in\mathbb{R}^{3}bold_s âˆˆ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Similarly, the residual for the jğ‘—jitalic_j-th line correspondence is reparameterized as

ğ«lâ¢jâ¢(ğ¬,ğ­)=[ğ©jhâŠ¤ğªjhâŠ¤]â¢[ğ‘^BEâ¢expâ¢(ğ¬âˆ§)ğ­âˆ§â¢ğ‘^BEâ¢expâ¢(ğ¬âˆ§)]â¢ğ‹j.subscriptğ«ğ‘™ğ‘—ğ¬ğ­matrixsuperscriptsubscriptğ©ğ‘—limit-fromâ„topsuperscriptsubscriptğªğ‘—limit-fromâ„topsuperscript^ğ‘BEexpsuperscriptğ¬superscriptğ­superscript^ğ‘BEexpsuperscriptğ¬subscriptğ‹ğ‘—{\bf r}_{lj}({\bf s},{\bf t})=\begin{bmatrix}{\bf p}_{j}^{h\top}\\ {\bf q}_{j}^{h\top}\end{bmatrix}\left[\hat{\bf R}^{\rm BE}{\rm exp}({\bf s}^{% \wedge})\leavevmode\nobreak\ \leavevmode\nobreak\ {\bf t}^{\wedge}\hat{\bf R}^% {\rm BE}{\rm exp}({\bf s}^{\wedge})\right]{\bf L}_{j}.bold_r start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_s , bold_t ) = [ start_ARG start_ROW start_CELL bold_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_h âŠ¤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL bold_q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_h âŠ¤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_CELL end_ROW end_ARG ] [ over^ start_ARG bold_R end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_BE end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_exp ( bold_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ§ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) bold_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ§ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT over^ start_ARG bold_R end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_BE end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_exp ( bold_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ§ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ] bold_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT .

After the above reparameterization, the standard GN algorithm over Euclidean space can be applied. The Jacobian matrix of the objective function in the ML problemÂ (13) at the point (0,ğ­^BE)0superscript^ğ­BE(0,\hat{\bf t}^{\rm BE})( 0 , over^ start_ARG bold_t end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_BE end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) is

ğ‰=[â‹®â‹®ğšºâˆ’12â¢âˆ‚ğ«pâ¢iâˆ‚ğ¬âŠ¤ğšºâˆ’12â¢âˆ‚ğ«pâ¢iâˆ‚ğ­âŠ¤â‹®â‹®âˆ‚ğšºjâˆ’12â¢ğ«lâ¢jâˆ‚ğ¬âŠ¤âˆ‚ğšºjâˆ’12â¢ğ«lâ¢jâˆ‚ğ­âŠ¤â‹®â‹®]|ğ¬=0,ğ­=ğ­^BE,Ïƒ2=Ïƒ^2,ğ‰evaluated-atmatrixâ‹®â‹®superscriptğšº12subscriptğ«ğ‘ğ‘–superscriptğ¬topsuperscriptğšº12subscriptğ«ğ‘ğ‘–superscriptğ­topâ‹®â‹®superscriptsubscriptğšºğ‘—12subscriptğ«ğ‘™ğ‘—superscriptğ¬topsuperscriptsubscriptğšºğ‘—12subscriptğ«ğ‘™ğ‘—superscriptğ­topâ‹®â‹®formulae-sequenceğ¬0formulae-sequenceğ­superscript^ğ­BEsuperscriptğœ2superscript^ğœ2{\bf J}=\left.\begin{bmatrix}\vdots&\vdots\\ \frac{{\bm{\Sigma}}^{-\frac{1}{2}}\partial{\bf r}_{pi}}{\partial{\bf s}^{\top}% }&\frac{{\bm{\Sigma}}^{-\frac{1}{2}}\partial{\bf r}_{pi}}{\partial{\bf t}^{% \top}}\\ \vdots&\vdots\\ \frac{\partial{\bm{\Sigma}}_{j}^{-\frac{1}{2}}{\bf r}_{lj}}{\partial{\bf s}^{% \top}}&\frac{\partial{\bm{\Sigma}}_{j}^{-\frac{1}{2}}{\bf r}_{lj}}{\partial{% \bf t}^{\top}}\\ \vdots&\vdots\end{bmatrix}\right|_{{\bf s}=0,{\bf t}=\hat{\bf t}^{\rm BE},% \sigma^{2}=\hat{\sigma}^{2}},bold_J = [ start_ARG start_ROW start_CELL â‹® end_CELL start_CELL â‹® end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL divide start_ARG bold_Î£ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - Finally, the GN-refined rotation matrix estimate can be obtained via the retraction map:

ğ‘^GN=ğ‘^BEâ¢expâ¢(ğ¬^GNâˆ§).superscript^ğ‘GNsuperscript^ğ‘BEexpsuperscriptsuperscript^ğ¬GN\hat{{\bf R}}^{\rm GN}=\hat{{\bf R}}^{\rm BE}{\rm exp}\left({{}\hat{{\bf s}}^{% \rm GN}}^{\wedge}\right).over^ start_ARG bold_R end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_GN end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = over^ start_ARG bold_R end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_BE end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_exp ( over^ start_ARG bold_s end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_GN end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ§ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) . (27)

Now, we give the asymptotic property of the refined estimate obtained from the one-step GN iterationÂ (26) andÂ (27).

Theorem 7.

Given the n+mğ‘›ğ‘š\sqrt{n+m}square-root start_ARG italic_n + italic_m end_ARG-consistency of the initial estimate [ğ‘^BEâ¢ğ­^BE]delimited-[]superscript^ğ‘BEsuperscript^ğ­BE[\hat{\bf R}^{\rm BE}\leavevmode\nobreak\ \hat{\bf t}^{\rm BE}][ over^ start_ARG bold_R end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_BE end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT over^ start_ARG bold_t end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_BE end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ], the GN-refined estimate [ğ‘^GNâ¢ğ­^GN]delimited-[]superscript^ğ‘GNsuperscript^ğ­GN[\hat{\bf R}^{\rm GN}\leavevmode\nobreak\ \hat{\bf t}^{\rm GN}][ over^ start_ARG bold_R end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_GN end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT over^ start_ARG bold_t end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_GN end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ] follows

ğ‘^GNâˆ’ğ‘^ML=opâ¢(1n+m),ğ­^GNâˆ’ğ­^ML=opâ¢(1n+m).formulae-sequencesuperscript^ğ‘GNsuperscript^ğ‘MLsubscriptğ‘œğ‘1ğ‘›ğ‘šsuperscript^ğ­GNsuperscript^ğ­MLsubscriptğ‘œğ‘1ğ‘›ğ‘š\hat{\bf R}^{\rm GN}-\hat{\bf R}^{\rm ML}=o_{p}(\frac{1}{\sqrt{n+m}}),\hat{\bf t% }^{\rm GN}-\hat{\bf t}^{\rm ML}=o_{p}(\frac{1}{\sqrt{n+m}}).over^ start_ARG bold_R end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_GN end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - over^ start_ARG bold_R end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_ML end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = italic_o start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG square-root start_ARG italic_n + italic_m end_ARG end_ARG ) , over^ start_ARG bold_t end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_GN end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - over^ start_ARG bold_t end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_ML end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = italic_o start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG square-root start_ARG italic_n + italic_m end_ARG end_ARG ) .

The proof of TheoremÂ 7 is presented in AppendixÂ C. The opsubscriptğ‘œğ‘o_{p}italic_o start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUBSCRIPT relationship implies that the one-step GN solution possesses the same asymptotic properties (consistency and asymptotic efficiency) as the ML estimateÂ [43, 49, 45]. In other words, [ğ‘^GNâ¢ğ­^GN]delimited-[]superscript^ğ‘GNsuperscript^ğ­GN[\hat{\bf R}^{\rm GN}\leavevmode\nobreak\ \hat{\bf t}^{\rm GN}][ over^ start_ARG bold_R end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_GN end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT over^ start_ARG bold_t end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_GN end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ] asymptotically reaches the CRB as [ğ‘^MLâ¢ğ­^ML]delimited-[]superscript^ğ‘MLsuperscript^ğ­ML[\hat{\bf R}^{\rm ML}\leavevmode\nobreak\ \hat{\bf t}^{\rm ML}][ over^ start_ARG bold_R end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_ML end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT over^ start_ARG bold_t end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_ML end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ] does, i.e., [ğ‘^GNâ¢ğ­^GN]delimited-[]superscript^ğ‘GNsuperscript^ğ­GN[\hat{\bf R}^{\rm GN}\leavevmode\nobreak\ \hat{\bf t}^{\rm GN}][ over^ start_ARG bold_R end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_GN end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT over^ start_ARG bold_t end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_GN end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ] is an asymptotically efficient estimate. For the derivation of the CRB, please refer to AppendixÂ D.

We end this section with a summary of the proposed consistent and asymptotically efficient estimator:

  • â€¢

    Algorithm framework. Our algorithm adopts a two-step scheme: In the first step, a consistent noise variance estimate is calculated, based on which a bias-eliminated and consistent pose estimate is obtained; In the second step, a single GN iteration is executed to refine the consistent estimate. The algorithm is uniformâ€”it is universally applicable for point-only, line-only, or combined point and line correspondences. In the first step, it adaptively selects which measurements to be utilized according to the values of nğ‘›nitalic_n and mğ‘šmitalic_m, as illustrated at the end of SectionÂ 5. In the second step, all measurements can be used to refine the initial result regardless of the values of nğ‘›nitalic_n and mğ‘šmitalic_m.

  • â€¢

    Estimation accuracy. Theoretically, we have proven that the proposed two-step estimator optimally solves the ML problem in the large sample case and is asymptotically efficientâ€”its covariance can asymptotically reach the CRB. This enables the full exploitation of a large number of feature measurements and yields a highly accurate pose estimate. In practice when dealing with real images, detected 2D points in pixel coordinates and 3D lines are normalized, and the recovery of the pose from unconstrained vectors of different sizes is elaborately devised to make the algorithm more stable and robust.

  • â€¢

    Time complexity. The capability of real-time implementation is an important evaluation metric for an algorithm used in robotic applications. Since the solutions in the first step can be calculated analytically (recall that both noise variance estimate and pose estimate are obtained via eigendecomposition) and only a single GN iteration is performed in the second step, it can be verified that each step in our estimator costs Oâ¢(n+m)ğ‘‚ğ‘›ğ‘šO(n+m)italic_O ( italic_n + italic_m ) time. Therefore, the total time complexity of our algorithm is Oâ¢(n+m)ğ‘‚ğ‘›ğ‘šO(n+m)italic_O ( italic_n + italic_m ), i.e., the cost time increases linearly w.r.t. the number of point/line correspondences.

7 Experiments

In this section, we compare our algorithms, referred to as AOPnP (for only point correspondences), AOPnL (for only line correspondences), and AOPnPL (for combined point and line correspondences), with some well-known and state-of-the-art camera pose solvers, including PnP algorithms (EPnPÂ [4], MLPnPÂ [5], DLSÂ [22], SQPnPÂ [6]), PnL algorithms (ASPnLÂ [7], SRPnLÂ [8], Ro_PnLÂ [9], AlgLSÂ [30]), and PnPL algorithms (EPnPLÂ [10], OPnPLÂ [10], EPnPLUÂ [11], DLSLUÂ [11]). The compared algorithms are implemented using available open source codes.

We conduct three kinds of experiments: In SubsectionÂ 7.1, simulations with synthetic data are designed to verify the correctness of our theoretical claims, including asymptotic unbiasedness, consistency, asymptotic efficiency, and linear time complexity of the proposed estimators; In SubsectionÂ 7.2, static real image tests are implemented with datasets ETH3DÂ [41] and VGGÂ [42] for PnP, PnL, and PnPL estimators, respectively. This corresponds to the applications of absolute pose estimation for a robot in a known environment. In SubsectionÂ 7.3, visual odometry experiments are performed with the EuRoC MAV datasetÂ [50]. This corresponds to the applications of robot localization and navigation in an unknown environment.

7.1 Simulations with synthetic data

Throughout the simulations, the Euler angles are set as [Ï€/3â¢Ï€/3â¢Ï€/3]âŠ¤superscriptdelimited-[]ğœ‹3ğœ‹3ğœ‹3top[\pi/3\leavevmode\nobreak\ \pi/3\leavevmode\nobreak\ \pi/3]^{\top}[ italic_Ï€ / 3 italic_Ï€ / 3 italic_Ï€ / 3 ] start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âŠ¤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, and the translation vector is [2 2 2]âŠ¤superscriptdelimited-[]222top[2\leavevmode\nobreak\ 2\leavevmode\nobreak\ 2]^{\top}[ 2 2 2 ] start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âŠ¤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. For the camera intrinsic parameters, the focal length is set as f=50ğ‘“50f=50italic_f = 50mm (800800800800 pixels), and the size of the image plane is 640Ã—480640480640\times 480640 Ã— 480 pixels. The intrinsic matrix is given by

ğŠ=[80003200800240001]â¢pixels.ğŠmatrix80003200800240001pixels{\bf K}=\begin{bmatrix}800&0&320\\ 0&800&240\\ 0&0&1\end{bmatrix}\leavevmode\nobreak\ {\rm pixels}.bold_K = [ start_ARG start_ROW start_CELL 800 end_CELL start_CELL 0 end_CELL start_CELL 320 end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL 0 end_CELL start_CELL 800 end_CELL start_CELL 240 end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL 0 end_CELL start_CELL 0 end_CELL start_CELL 1 end_CELL end_ROW end_ARG ] roman_pixels .

For data generation, we first randomly generate nğ‘›nitalic_n points and 2â¢m2ğ‘š2m2 italic_m endpoints of mğ‘šmitalic_m lines in the image plane. Then, these points are endowed with a random depth between [2,10]210[2,10][ 2 , 10 ]m, yielding their 3D coordinates in the camera frame. Further, the coordinates in the camera frame are transformed into the world frame using the true pose value, by which nğ‘›nitalic_n 3D points and mğ‘šmitalic_m 3D lines have been generated. Finally, nğ‘›nitalic_n 2D points and 2â¢m2ğ‘š2m2 italic_m 2D endpoints in the image plane are corrupted by i.i.d. Gaussian noises with zero mean and Ïƒğœ\sigmaitalic_Ïƒ (pixels) standard deviation.

In terms of estimation accuracy, we compare the mean squared error (MSE) of each estimator. The MSE is approximated as

MSEâ¢(ğ‘^)MSE^ğ‘\displaystyle{\rm MSE}(\hat{\bf R})roman_MSE ( over^ start_ARG bold_R end_ARG ) =1Kâ¢âˆ‘k=1Kâ€–ğ‘^â¢(Ï‰k)âˆ’ğ‘oâ€–F2,absent1ğ¾superscriptsubscriptğ‘˜1ğ¾superscriptsubscriptnorm^ğ‘subscriptğœ”ğ‘˜superscriptğ‘ğ‘œF2\displaystyle=\frac{1}{K}\sum\limits_{k=1}^{K}{\|\hat{\bf R}(\omega_{k})-{\bf R% }^{o}\|}_{\rm F}^{2},= divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_K end_ARG âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ¥ over^ start_ARG bold_R end_ARG ( italic_Ï‰ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) - bold_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_o end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ¥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_F end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ,
MSEâ¢(ğ­^)MSE^ğ­\displaystyle{\rm MSE}(\hat{\bf t})roman_MSE ( over^ start_ARG bold_t end_ARG ) =1Kâ¢âˆ‘k=1Kâ€–ğ­^â¢(Ï‰k)âˆ’ğ­oâ€–2,absent1ğ¾superscriptsubscriptğ‘˜1ğ¾superscriptnorm^ğ­subscriptğœ”ğ‘˜superscriptğ­ğ‘œ2\displaystyle=\frac{1}{K}\sum\limits_{k=1}^{K}{\|\hat{\bf t}(\omega_{k})-{\bf t% }^{o}\|}^{2},= divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_K end_ARG âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ¥ over^ start_ARG bold_t end_ARG ( italic_Ï‰ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) - bold_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_o end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ¥ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ,

where Kğ¾Kitalic_K is the number of Monte Carlo tests, and (ğ‘^â¢(Ï‰k),ğ­^â¢(Ï‰k))^ğ‘subscriptğœ”ğ‘˜^ğ­subscriptğœ”ğ‘˜(\hat{\bf R}(\omega_{k}),\hat{\bf t}(\omega_{k}))( over^ start_ARG bold_R end_ARG ( italic_Ï‰ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) , over^ start_ARG bold_t end_ARG ( italic_Ï‰ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ) is the estimated pose in the kğ‘˜kitalic_k-th test. Throughout the simulations, we set K=1000ğ¾1000K=1000italic_K = 1000. The scalar bias is approximated as

Î”â¢ğ‘Î”ğ‘\displaystyle\Delta{\bf R}roman_Î” bold_R =|1Kâ¢âˆ‘k=1Kğ‘^â¢(Ï‰k)âˆ’ğ‘o|,Biasâ¢(ğ‘^)=âˆ‘i=13âˆ‘j=13[Î”â¢ğ‘]iâ¢jformulae-sequenceabsent1ğ¾superscriptsubscriptğ‘˜1ğ¾^ğ‘subscriptğœ”ğ‘˜superscriptğ‘ğ‘œBias^ğ‘superscriptsubscriptğ‘–13superscriptsubscriptğ‘—13subscriptdelimited-[]Î”ğ‘ğ‘–ğ‘—\displaystyle=\left|\frac{1}{K}\sum_{k=1}^{K}\hat{\bf R}(\omega_{k})-{\bf R}^{% o}\right|,\leavevmode\nobreak\ \leavevmode\nobreak\ {\rm Bias}(\hat{\bf R})=% \sum_{i=1}^{3}\sum_{j=1}^{3}[\Delta{\bf R}]_{ij}= | divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_K end_ARG âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT over^ start_ARG bold_R end_ARG ( italic_Ï‰ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) - bold_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_o end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT | , roman_Bias ( over^ start_ARG bold_R end_ARG ) = âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT [ roman_Î” bold_R ] start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT
Î”â¢ğ­Î”ğ­\displaystyle\Delta{\bf t}roman_Î” bold_t =|1Kâ¢âˆ‘k=1Kğ­^â¢(Ï‰k)âˆ’ğ­o|,Biasâ¢(ğ­^)=âˆ‘i=13[Î”â¢ğ­]i.formulae-sequenceabsent1ğ¾superscriptsubscriptğ‘˜1ğ¾^ğ­subscriptğœ”ğ‘˜superscriptğ­ğ‘œBias^ğ­superscriptsubscriptğ‘–13subscriptdelimited-[]Î”ğ­ğ‘–\displaystyle=\left|\frac{1}{K}\sum_{k=1}^{K}\hat{\bf t}(\omega_{k})-{\bf t}^{% o}\right|,\leavevmode\nobreak\ \leavevmode\nobreak\ {\rm Bias}(\hat{\bf t})=% \sum_{i=1}^{3}[\Delta{\bf t}]_{i}.= | divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_K end_ARG âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT over^ start_ARG bold_t end_ARG ( italic_Ï‰ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) - bold_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_o end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT | , roman_Bias ( over^ start_ARG bold_t end_ARG ) = âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT [ roman_Î” bold_t ] start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT .

(1) Consistency of noise variance estimators. To devise consistent pose estimators, we first derive consistent estimators for measurement noise variance, as shown in TheoremsÂ 2,Â 4, andÂ 6. We let n=m=10,30,100,300,1000formulae-sequenceğ‘›ğ‘š10301003001000n=m=10,30,100,300,1000italic_n = italic_m = 10 , 30 , 100 , 300 , 1000 and Ïƒ=5,10ğœ510\sigma=5,10italic_Ïƒ = 5 , 10 pixels. FigureÂ 4 presents the MSEs of noise variance estimates, where double logarithmic axes have been used. We see that the MSEs decline linearly w.r.t. the measurement number, which validates that the proposed noise variance estimators are all n+mğ‘›ğ‘š\sqrt{n+m}square-root start_ARG italic_n + italic_m end_ARG-consistent. The MSEs using points are lower than those using lines. In addition, the MSEs by combining points and lines are the lowest, which coincides with intuition.

(2) Asymptotic unbiasedness of pose estimators. As stated before, inÂ (16),Â (20), andÂ (23), the regressor is correlated with the noise term. Without bias elimination, the estimates derived from these equations are not asymptotically unbiased. Based on the estimate of noise variance, the proposed bias elimination method can eliminate the asymptotic bias. These claims are verified in FigureÂ 5, where we use â€œw.o.â€ and â€œBEâ€ for the abbreviations of â€œwithoutâ€ and â€œbias eliminationâ€, respectively. Without bias elimination, the biases of the estimators converge to a nonzero value, although the PnPL estimator achieves a much smaller bias compared to the PnP and PnL estimators. The biases of the proposed bias-eliminated estimators all converge to 00, implying that they are asymptotically unbiased.

(3) Consistency and asymptotic efficiency of pose estimators. We have proved that the proposed estimator is n+mğ‘›ğ‘š\sqrt{n+m}square-root start_ARG italic_n + italic_m end_ARG-consistent in its first step, based on which a single GN iteration suffices to reach the CRB, i.e., the proposed two-step estimator is asymptotically efficient. The MSE comparison among different PnP pose estimators is presented in FigureÂ 6. It is obvious from FigureÂ 6(d) that the MSEs of the DLS, EPnP, and SQPnP estimators do not converge to 00. This is because they are not asymptotically unbiased, and their asymptotic MSEs are dominated by asymptotic biases. We can see that when nâ‰¥30ğ‘›30n\geq 30italic_n â‰¥ 30, our estimator AOPnP can reach the CRB, coinciding with our theoretical claims. The CRB converges to 00, which shows that the more point correspondences, the more accurate the estimate is. It is noteworthy that the MLPnP estimator seems to be also asymptotically efficient. This is because it performs multiple GN iterations. The attraction neighborhood of the global minimum ofÂ (13) is relatively large in this scenario. As a result, although the initial value is not consistent, it can still fall into the attraction neighborhood, and multiple GN iterations can find the global minimum. In AppendixÂ E, we set Ïƒ=50ğœ50\sigma=50italic_Ïƒ = 50 pixels. In this case, the initial value of the MLPnP falls beyond the attraction neighborhood, and the MLPnP estimate cannot reach the CRB.

The MSE comparison among different PnL pose estimators is presented in FigureÂ 7. We see that the proposed AOPnL estimator can asymptotically reach the CRB. In addition, it outperforms the other estimators significantly. It seems that the compared PnL estimators are less stable than previous PnP estimators. When Ïƒ=10ğœ10\sigma=10italic_Ïƒ = 10 pixels, the MSEs of the ASPnL, SRPnL, and AlgLS estimators fluctuate w.r.t. the line number.

Finally, we compare different PnPL estimators which utilize both point and line correspondences. The result is shown in FigureÂ 8. The proposed estimator AOPnPL can asymptotically reach the CRB. It is noteworthy that when the measurement number is relatively small, the AOPnPL estimator may outperform the CRB. This is because the CRB is a lower bound for unbiased estimators, while the proposed estimator is not necessarily unbiased in a finite sample case. For the comparison estimators, they are less accurate than ours. Especially in the case of a large measurement number and noise intensity, the proposed AOPnPL can outperform the other estimators more than 10 times.

The MSE comparison of our proposed estimators using different kinds of measurements is shown in FigureÂ 9. We see that using only point correspondences or only line correspondences leads to comparable MSEs. This is because the intensity of the noises added to points and endpoints of lines is the same, and each point or line correspondence yields two independent equations. By fusing point and line measurements, the AOPnPL estimator can achieve an MSE smaller than half of that of the AOPnP and AOPnL estimators.

(4) Linear time complexity of pose estimators. Since the solution in the first step can be calculated analytically, and only a single GN iteration is performed in the second step, the total time complexity of our algorithm is Oâ¢(n+m)ğ‘‚ğ‘›ğ‘šO(n+m)italic_O ( italic_n + italic_m ), i.e., the cost time increases linearly w.r.t. the measurement number. The accumulated CPU time (over 1000100010001000 Monte Carlo tests) of all tested algorithms is presented in FigureÂ 10. Apart from the SQPnP using Python implementation, all algorithms are executed with MATLAB codes. We see that the CPU time of our proposed algorithm increases linearly w.r.t. the measurement number. Among all tested algorithms, our proposed one is at an intermediate level. Some estimators, such as Ro_PnL and ASPnL, may be unable to be implemented in real time when the measurement number is large.

7.2 Static real image tests

In this subsection, we conduct static real image tests, which correspond to the applications of absolute robot pose estimation in a pre-reconstructed map. First, we compare PnP estimators with the ETH3D datasetÂ [41]. The dataset has 13131313 scenes, each of which contains dozens of images. FigureÂ 11 gives the mean estimation errors of PnP estimators in all scenes. In most scenes, our estimator AOPnP achieves the smallest errors. Resembling the simulation, the MLPnP algorithm owns a comparable accuracy with AOPnP, while the other estimators have much larger estimation errors.

We select four scenes where our estimator has the smallest mean errors and plot the error distribution in FigureÂ 12. We find that the reason why the AOPnP estimator performs best is two-fold: First, it produces less severe outlier estimates; Second, it has lower quartiles.

To test the relationship between the MSEs and point number nğ‘›nitalic_n, we randomly select four images that have abundant point correspondences. In each trial, we randomly select a certain number of points to infer the camera pose, and the MSEs are calculated by 100100100100 Monte Carlo trials. The result is plotted in FigureÂ 13. We see that the MSE of our AOPnP solver consistently declines as nğ‘›nitalic_n increases. Moreover, it significantly outperforms the EPnP, DLS, and SQPnP estimators when nğ‘›nitalic_n is relatively large. Although the MLPnP estimator has a similar MSE to AOPnP, noting that it has high time complexity, our algorithm performs best by taking both accuracy and efficiency into account.

Second, we compare PnL estimators with the VGG datasetÂ [42]. FigureÂ 14 presents the mean estimation errors of PnL estimators in the tested scenes. Our estimator AOPnL achieves the smallest errors except for the Model House scene. Moreover, the magnitude of superiority is significant and sometimes can reach 3333 orders. The reason why AOPnL has large average errors in the Model House scene is that there are two images with relatively few lines and AOPnL produces abnormal pose estimates. Since each scene only contains several images, we do not plot the corresponding error distribution.

We select four images and reproject 3D lines onto the images using estimated poses to show the estimation precision qualitatively. As shown in FigureÂ 15, with the estimated poses by our estimator, the projected lines coincide with the given 2D lines well, whereas the other estimators generate deviated lines, especially the Ro_PnL and ASPnL methods with lines in the sky or on the grass. The result of the AlgLS estimator is omitted because its estimation errors are too large and the lines cannot be displayed in the images.

We use the four images in FigureÂ 15 to test the relationship between the MSEs and line number mğ‘šmitalic_m. In each trial, we randomly select a certain number of lines to infer the camera pose, and the MSEs are calculated by 100100100100 Monte Carlo trials. The result is plotted in FigureÂ 16. The MSE of our AOPnL solver declines as mğ‘šmitalic_m increases. In addition, it is much smaller than that of the other methods. The Ro_PnL and SRPnL estimators seem not so stable and the AlgLS estimator has the largest MSE.

Finally, we compare PnPL estimators with the VGG dataset. FigureÂ 17 presents the mean estimation errors of PnPL estimators in the tested scenes. In practice, we find that the noise variances of points and lines can be quite different, hence we estimate them separately. Note that the EPnPLU and DLSU estimators need extra prior information about uncertainties of 2D projections and the average scene depth. We use the true scene depth and our estimated noise variance as their inputs. We see that the proposed AOPnL estimator performs best, especially for the estimation of orientation. Even though the EPnPLU and DLSU methods utilize the true depth scene, our estimator has better accuracy.

7.3 Visual odometry with real image sequences

In the last subsection, we have tested the static camera pose estimation which corresponds to robot localization in a known 3D map. A more common scenario is that a robot explores and navigates in an unknown environment, which involves SLAM or odometry. In this subsection, we embed PnP estimators into a stereo visual odometry pipeline and compare the accuracy and efficiency using the EuRoC MAV datasetÂ [50]. The odometry mainly includes three components: feature extraction and tracking, triangulation, and PnP solver. Harris corners are extracted on the left image first, and then their correspondences on the right image are found by Lucas-Kanade (L-K) optical flow. To reject outliers, inverse L-K optical flow is employed. Feature tracking is only performed on the left camera, which is also done by L-K optical flow. Fundamental-matrix-based RANSAC is adopted to improve the quality of point correspondences. Once the correspondences are established, the depth of feature points can be obtained by triangulation, using the extrinsics between stereo cameras. The points tracked on the left camera can be triangulated based on the relative pose given by the previous estimation. With the triangulated 3D points and their 2D correspondences, we utilize iterative-PnP-based RANSAC to filter outliers. Finally, the inliers will be fed into a PnP algorithm to obtain the frame-to-frame pose estimation. The PnP solver would be replaced by different algorithms, while the other components remain unchanged.

We select four sequences labeled â€œeasyâ€ in the EuRoC dataset since they exhibit less dynamic motion, allowing the extraction of high-quality feature points and their correspondences. The maximum number of points extracted in one frame is limited to 1000, and the distance between every two points should be greater than 15 pixels, which can promote uniform distribution of features in the image. The extrinsics between stereo cameras are given by dataset defaults. All algorithms are run on an Intel-13500H mobile CPU upon WSL2 (Windows Subsystem Linux).

FigureÂ 18 plots the real-time absolute pose error (APE) at each instant, and TableÂ 1 gives the APE RMSE where â€œ/â€ represents that the corresponding PnP algorithm fails to generate a reasonable odometry. Other than the MH01 sequence, the proposed AOPnP algorithm consistently has the smallest APE RMSE, and the superiority is significant for the VR201 sequence. The APE RMSE of AOPnP is slightly inferior to the MLPnP estimator in the MH01 sequence. It is noteworthy that the DLS and EPnP algorithms both fail in all sequences. This is because their pose estimation precision is relatively low and the accumulated drift rapidly increases to an abnormal value. The instantaneous APE figure supports the RMSE result. The estimated trajectory is plotted in FigureÂ 19. Overall, the trajectory based on AOPnP coincides with the ground truth best, especially in the VR201 sequence. The MLPnP algorithm has a comparable performance with the proposed one in the other three sequences, which is better than the SQPnP algorithm.

TableÂ 2 lists the CPU time consumed by each PnP algorithm in the odometry process. The SQPnP algorithm owns the lowest time complexity since it invokes only a small number of local searches. Compared with MLPnP, the proposed AOPnP estimator is about four times faster, which can save time for other pipelines in a comprehensive SLAM or odometry system while maintaining a relatively high accuracy.

In summary, in the dynamic odometry evaluation, our proposed AOPnP estimator features the best estimation accuracy while possessing a relatively low time complexity. When combined with a feature extraction and tracking module that can yield plenty of high-quality correspondences, it is well-suited for precision-demanding and real-time SLAM applications.

8 Conclusion and future work

In this paper, we proposed a uniform camera-robot pose estimation algorithm that can take points, lines, or combined points and lines as inputs. By virtue of noise variance estimation and bias elimination, the algorithm is asymptotically unbiased and consistent in the first step. Then, an ensuing single GN iteration in the second step makes the estimate to be asymptotically efficient. Thanks to the simple form in each step, our estimator scales linearly with respect to the feature number. Three kinds of experiments showed the advantages of the proposed algorithm in terms of estimation accuracy and time complexity. To fully unleash the potential of the proposed algorithm, it is desirable to equip it with a frontend that can extract and match a relatively large number of high-quality features.

In future work, a more concise pose parameterization method may be adopted to improve the estimation accuracy when the feature number is few while maintaining the properties of consistency and asymptotic efficiency. In addition, how to achieve consistency against outlier feature correspondences in some outlier-prone scenarios is also an interesting problem.

Appendix A Proof of TheoremsÂ 1 andÂ 3

The proof is mainly based on the following lemma:

Lemma 2 ([49, Lemma 4]).

For the other claim, note that (1). ğnBEsuperscriptsubscriptğğ‘›BE{\bf Q}_{n}^{\rm BE}bold_Q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_BE end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT converges to ğnosuperscriptsubscriptğğ‘›ğ‘œ{\bf Q}_{n}^{o}bold_Q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_o end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT with a rate of 1/n1ğ‘›1/\sqrt{n}1 / square-root start_ARG italic_n end_ARG; (2). eigenvectors are continuously changing w.r.t. the varying of a matrix; (3). ğœ½Â¯osuperscriptÂ¯ğœ½ğ‘œ\bar{\bm{\theta}}^{o}overÂ¯ start_ARG bold_italic_Î¸ end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_o end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is a unit vector corresponding to the smallest eigenvalue of ğnosuperscriptsubscriptğğ‘›ğ‘œ{\bf Q}_{n}^{o}bold_Q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_o end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. To prove TheoremÂ 3, let

Î”â¢ğ€mâ‰œğ€mâˆ’ğ€mo=[[Ïµğ©1hâ¢Ïµğª1h]âŠ¤â¢ğ‹Â¯1â‹®[Ïµğ©mhâ¢Ïµğªmh]âŠ¤â¢ğ‹Â¯m].â‰œÎ”subscriptğ€ğ‘šsubscriptğ€ğ‘šsuperscriptsubscriptğ€ğ‘šğ‘œmatrixsuperscriptdelimited-[]superscriptsubscriptbold-italic-Ïµsubscriptğ©1â„superscriptsubscriptbold-italic-Ïµsubscriptğª1â„topsubscriptÂ¯ğ‹1â‹®superscriptdelimited-[]superscriptsubscriptbold-italic-Ïµsubscriptğ©ğ‘šâ„superscriptsubscriptbold-italic-Ïµsubscriptğªğ‘šâ„topsubscriptÂ¯ğ‹ğ‘š\Delta{\bf A}_{m}\triangleq{\bf A}_{m}-{\bf A}_{m}^{o}=\begin{bmatrix}[{\bm{% \epsilon}}_{{\bf p}_{1}}^{h}\leavevmode\nobreak\ {\bm{\epsilon}}_{{\bf q}_{1}}% ^{h}]^{\top}\mkern 2.5mu\overline{\mkern-2.5mu\bf L\mkern-2.5mu}\mkern 2.5mu_{% 1}\\ \vdots\\ [{\bm{\epsilon}}_{{\bf p}_{m}}^{h}\leavevmode\nobreak\ {\bm{\epsilon}}_{{\bf q% }_{m}}^{h}]^{\top}\mkern 2.5mu\overline{\mkern-2.5mu\bf L\mkern-2.5mu}\mkern 2% .5mu_{m}\end{bmatrix}.roman_Î” bold_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‰œ bold_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - bold_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_o end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = [ start_ARG start_ROW start_CELL [ bold_italic_Ïµ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_h end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_italic_Ïµ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_h end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ] start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âŠ¤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT overÂ¯ start_ARG bold_L end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL â‹® end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL [ bold_italic_Ïµ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_h end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_italic_Ïµ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_h end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ] start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âŠ¤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT overÂ¯ start_ARG bold_L end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_CELL end_ROW end_ARG ] .

Then, we have

ğmâˆ’ğmosubscriptğğ‘šsuperscriptsubscriptğğ‘šğ‘œ\displaystyle{\bf Q}_{m}-{\bf Q}_{m}^{o}bold_Q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - bold_Q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_o end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT =1mâ¢(Î”â¢ğ€mâŠ¤â¢ğ€mo+ğ€moâŠ¤â¢Î”â¢ğ€m+Î”â¢ğ€mâŠ¤â¢Î”â¢ğ€m)absent1ğ‘šÎ”superscriptsubscriptğ€ğ‘štopsuperscriptsubscriptğ€ğ‘šğ‘œsuperscriptsubscriptğ€ğ‘šlimit-fromğ‘œtopÎ”subscriptğ€ğ‘šÎ”superscriptsubscriptğ€ğ‘štopÎ”subscriptğ€ğ‘š\displaystyle=\frac{1}{m}(\Delta{\bf A}_{m}^{\top}{\bf A}_{m}^{o}+{\bf A}_{m}^% {o\top}\Delta{\bf A}_{m}+\Delta{\bf A}_{m}^{\top}\Delta{\bf A}_{m})= divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_m end_ARG ( roman_Î” bold_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âŠ¤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_o end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + bold_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_o âŠ¤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_Î” bold_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + roman_Î” bold_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âŠ¤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_Î” bold_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT )
=1mâ¢(Î”â¢ğ€mâŠ¤â¢Î”â¢ğ€m)+Opâ¢(1/m)absent1ğ‘šÎ”superscriptsubscriptğ€ğ‘štopÎ”subscriptğ€ğ‘šsubscriptğ‘‚ğ‘1ğ‘š\displaystyle=\frac{1}{m}(\Delta{\bf A}_{m}^{\top}\Delta{\bf A}_{m})+O_{p}(1/% \sqrt{m})= divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_m end_ARG ( roman_Î” bold_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âŠ¤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_Î” bold_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) + italic_O start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( 1 / square-root start_ARG italic_m end_ARG )
=Ïƒ2mâ¢(ğ€~mâ¢1âŠ¤â¢ğ€~mâ¢1+ğ€~mâ¢2âŠ¤â¢ğ€~mâ¢2)+Opâ¢(1/m)absentsuperscriptğœ2ğ‘šsuperscriptsubscript~ğ€ğ‘š1topsubscript~ğ€ğ‘š1superscriptsubscript~ğ€ğ‘š2topsubscript~ğ€ğ‘š2subscriptğ‘‚ğ‘1ğ‘š\displaystyle=\frac{\sigma^{2}}{m}(\tilde{\bf A}_{m1}^{\top}\tilde{\bf A}_{m1}% +\tilde{\bf A}_{m2}^{\top}\tilde{\bf A}_{m2})+O_{p}(1/\sqrt{m})= divide start_ARG italic_Ïƒ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG italic_m end_ARG ( over~ start_ARG bold_A end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âŠ¤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT over~ start_ARG bold_A end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + over~ start_ARG bold_A end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âŠ¤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT over~ start_ARG bold_A end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) + italic_O start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( 1 / square-root start_ARG italic_m end_ARG )
=Ïƒ^m2â¢(ğ~mâ¢1+ğ~mâ¢2)+Opâ¢(1/m),absentsubscriptsuperscript^ğœ2ğ‘šsubscript~ğğ‘š1subscript~ğğ‘š2subscriptğ‘‚ğ‘1ğ‘š\displaystyle=\hat{\sigma}^{2}_{m}(\tilde{\bf Q}_{m1}+\tilde{\bf Q}_{m2})+O_{p% }(1/\sqrt{m}),= over^ start_ARG italic_Ïƒ end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( over~ start_ARG bold_Q end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + over~ start_ARG bold_Q end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) + italic_O start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( 1 / square-root start_ARG italic_m end_ARG ) ,

where the second and third â€œ===â€ are based on LemmaÂ 2, and the last â€œ===â€ attributes to the boundedness of ğ~mâ¢1subscript~ğğ‘š1\tilde{\bf Q}_{m1}over~ start_ARG bold_Q end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and ğ~mâ¢2subscript~ğğ‘š2\tilde{\bf Q}_{m2}over~ start_ARG bold_Q end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Hence,Â (22) holds. The other claim can be verified similarly to the point case and is omitted here.

Appendix B Derivatives in the GN iteration

Let

ğ«pâ¢idenâ¢(ğ¬,ğ­)superscriptsubscriptğ«ğ‘ğ‘–denğ¬ğ­\displaystyle{\bf r}_{pi}^{\rm den}({\bf s},{\bf t})bold_r start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_den end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( bold_s , bold_t ) â‰œğ3âŠ¤â¢(ğ‘^BEâ¢expâ¢(ğ¬âˆ§)â¢ğ—i+ğ­),â‰œabsentsuperscriptsubscriptğ3topsuperscript^ğ‘BEexpsuperscriptğ¬subscriptğ—ğ‘–ğ­\displaystyle\triangleq{\bf e}_{3}^{\top}(\hat{\bf R}^{\rm BE}{\rm exp}({\bf s% }^{\wedge}){\bf X}_{i}+{\bf t}),â‰œ bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âŠ¤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( over^ start_ARG bold_R end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_BE end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_exp ( bold_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ§ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) bold_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + bold_t ) ,
ğ«pâ¢inumâ¢(ğ¬,ğ­)superscriptsubscriptğ«ğ‘ğ‘–numğ¬ğ­\displaystyle{\bf r}_{pi}^{\rm num}({\bf s},{\bf t})bold_r start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_num end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( bold_s , bold_t ) â‰œğ„â¢(ğ‘^BEâ¢expâ¢(ğ¬âˆ§)â¢ğ—i+ğ­).â‰œabsentğ„superscript^ğ‘BEexpsuperscriptğ¬subscriptğ—ğ‘–ğ­\displaystyle\triangleq{\bf E}(\hat{\bf R}^{\rm BE}{\rm exp}({\bf s}^{\wedge})% {\bf X}_{i}+{\bf t}).â‰œ bold_E ( over^ start_ARG bold_R end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_BE end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_exp ( bold_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ§ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) bold_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + bold_t ) .

âˆ‚ğ«pâ¢iâˆ‚ğ¬âŠ¤|ğ¬=0\displaystyle\frac{\partial{\bf r}_{pi}}{\partial{\bf s}^{\top}}\big{\rvert}_{% {\bf s}=0}divide start_ARG âˆ‚ bold_r start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG âˆ‚ bold_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âŠ¤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG | start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_s = 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT =(ğ«pâ¢inumâ¢(0,ğ­)â¢ğ3âŠ¤âˆ’ğ«pâ¢idenâ¢(0,ğ­)â¢ğ„)â¢(ğ—iâŠ¤âŠ—ğ‘^BE)â¢ğš¿ğ«pâ¢idenâ¢(0,ğ­)2,absentsuperscriptsubscriptğ«ğ‘ğ‘–num0ğ­superscriptsubscriptğ3topsuperscriptsubscriptğ«ğ‘ğ‘–den0ğ­ğ„tensor-productsuperscriptsubscriptğ—ğ‘–topsuperscript^ğ‘BEğš¿superscriptsubscriptğ«ğ‘ğ‘–densuperscript0ğ­2\displaystyle=\frac{\left({\bf r}_{pi}^{\rm num}(0,{\bf t}){\bf e}_{3}^{\top}-% {\bf r}_{pi}^{\rm den}(0,{\bf t}){\bf E}\right)({\bf X}_{i}^{\top}\otimes\hat{% \bf R}^{\rm BE}){\bm{\Psi}}}{{\bf r}_{pi}^{\rm den}(0,{\bf t})^{2}},= divide start_ARG ( bold_r start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_num end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 0 , bold_t ) bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âŠ¤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - bold_r start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_den end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 0 , bold_t ) bold_E ) ( bold_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âŠ¤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âŠ— over^ start_ARG bold_R end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_BE end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) bold_Î¨ end_ARG start_ARG bold_r start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_den end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 0 , bold_t ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG ,

where

ğš¿â‰œâˆ‚vecâ¢(expâ¡(ğ¬âˆ§))âˆ‚ğ¬âŠ¤|ğ¬=ğŸ.{\bm{\Psi}}\triangleq\frac{\partial{\rm vec}(\exp(\bf s^{\wedge}))}{\partial{% \bf s}^{\top}}\Big{\rvert}_{\bf s=0}.bold_Î¨ â‰œ divide start_ARG âˆ‚ roman_vec ( roman_exp ( bold_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ§ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ) end_ARG start_ARG âˆ‚ bold_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âŠ¤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG | start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_s = bold_0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT .

Note that ğšºjâˆ’12â¢ğ«lâ¢j=[[ğ«lâ¢j]1/Ïƒj[ğ«lâ¢j]2/Ïƒj]âŠ¤superscriptsubscriptğšºğ‘—12subscriptğ«ğ‘™ğ‘—superscriptsubscriptdelimited-[]subscriptğ«ğ‘™ğ‘—1subscriptğœğ‘—subscriptdelimited-[]subscriptğ«ğ‘™ğ‘—2subscriptğœğ‘—top{\bm{\Sigma}}_{j}^{-\frac{1}{2}}{\bf r}_{lj}=[[{\bf r}_{lj}]_{1}/\sigma_{j}% \leavevmode\nobreak\ \leavevmode\nobreak\ [{\bf r}_{lj}]_{2}/\sigma_{j}]^{\top}bold_Î£ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_r start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = [ [ bold_r start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT / italic_Ïƒ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ bold_r start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT / italic_Ïƒ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âŠ¤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, where Ïƒj=Ïƒâ¢â€–[ğ¥Â¯j]1:2â€–subscriptğœğ‘—ğœnormsubscriptdelimited-[]subscriptÂ¯ğ¥ğ‘—:12\sigma_{j}=\sigma\|[\bar{\bf l}_{j}]_{1:2}\|italic_Ïƒ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_Ïƒ âˆ¥ [ overÂ¯ start_ARG bold_l end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 : 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¥. âˆ‚ğšºjâˆ’12â¢ğ«lâ¢jâˆ‚ğ¬âŠ¤|ğ¬=0\displaystyle\frac{\partial{\bm{\Sigma}}_{j}^{-\frac{1}{2}}{\bf r}_{lj}}{% \partial{\bf s}^{\top}}\big{\rvert}_{{\bf s}=0}divide start_ARG âˆ‚ bold_Î£ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - âˆ‚ğšºjâˆ’12â¢ğ«lâ¢jâˆ‚ğ­âŠ¤|ğ¬=0\displaystyle\frac{\partial{\bm{\Sigma}}_{j}^{-\frac{1}{2}}{\bf r}_{lj}}{% \partial{\bf t}^{\top}}\big{\rvert}_{{\bf s}=0}divide start_ARG âˆ‚ bold_Î£ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - Let ğ‹Â¯jâ¢1â‰œ[ğ‹j]1:3âŠ¤âŠ—ğˆ3â‰œsubscriptÂ¯ğ‹ğ‘—1tensor-productsuperscriptsubscriptdelimited-[]subscriptğ‹ğ‘—:13topsubscriptğˆ3\mkern 2.5mu\overline{\mkern-2.5mu\bf L\mkern-2.5mu}\mkern 2.5mu_{j1}% \triangleq[{\bf L}_{j}]_{1:3}^{\top}\otimes{\bf I}_{3}overÂ¯ start_ARG bold_L end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‰œ [ bold_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 : 3 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âŠ¤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âŠ— bold_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and ğ‹Â¯jâ¢2â‰œ[ğ‹j]4:6âŠ¤âŠ—ğˆ3â‰œsubscriptÂ¯ğ‹ğ‘—2tensor-productsuperscriptsubscriptdelimited-[]subscriptğ‹ğ‘—:46topsubscriptğˆ3\mkern 2.5mu\overline{\mkern-2.5mu\bf L\mkern-2.5mu}\mkern 2.5mu_{j2}% \triangleq[{\bf L}_{j}]_{4:6}^{\top}\otimes{\bf I}_{3}overÂ¯ start_ARG bold_L end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‰œ [ bold_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 4 : 6 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âŠ¤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âŠ— bold_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. We obtain

âˆ‚ğ«lâ¢jâˆ‚ğ¬âŠ¤|ğ¬=0\displaystyle\frac{\partial{\bf r}_{lj}}{\partial{\bf s}^{\top}}\big{\rvert}_{% {\bf s}=0}divide start_ARG âˆ‚ bold_r start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG âˆ‚ bold_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âŠ¤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG | start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_s = 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT =[ğ©jhâ¢ğªjh]âŠ¤â¢(ğ‹Â¯jâ¢1+ğ­âˆ§â¢ğ‹Â¯jâ¢2)â¢(ğˆ3âŠ—ğ‘^BE)â¢ğš¿,absentsuperscriptdelimited-[]superscriptsubscriptğ©ğ‘—â„superscriptsubscriptğªğ‘—â„topsubscriptÂ¯ğ‹ğ‘—1superscriptğ­subscriptÂ¯ğ‹ğ‘—2tensor-productsubscriptğˆ3superscript^ğ‘BEğš¿\displaystyle=[{\bf p}_{j}^{h}\leavevmode\nobreak\ {\bf q}_{j}^{h}]^{\top}% \left(\mkern 2.5mu\overline{\mkern-2.5mu\bf L\mkern-2.5mu}\mkern 2.5mu_{j1}+{% \bf t}^{\wedge}\mkern 2.5mu\overline{\mkern-2.5mu\bf L\mkern-2.5mu}\mkern 2.5% mu_{j2}\right)({\bf I}_{3}\otimes\hat{\bf R}^{\rm BE}){\bm{\Psi}},= [ bold_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_h end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_h end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ] start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âŠ¤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( overÂ¯ start_ARG bold_L end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + bold_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ§ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT overÂ¯ start_ARG bold_L end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ( bold_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âŠ— over^ start_ARG bold_R end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_BE end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) bold_Î¨ ,
âˆ‚ğ«lâ¢jâˆ‚ğ­âŠ¤|ğ¬=0\displaystyle\frac{\partial{\bf r}_{lj}}{\partial{\bf t}^{\top}}\big{\rvert}_{% {\bf s}=0}divide start_ARG âˆ‚ bold_r start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG âˆ‚ bold_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âŠ¤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG | start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_s = 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT =âˆ’[ğ©jhâ¢ğªjh]âŠ¤â¢(ğ‘^BEâ¢[ğ‹j]4:6)âˆ§,absentsuperscriptdelimited-[]superscriptsubscriptğ©ğ‘—â„superscriptsubscriptğªğ‘—â„topsuperscriptsuperscript^ğ‘BEsubscriptdelimited-[]subscriptğ‹ğ‘—:46\displaystyle=-[{\bf p}_{j}^{h}\leavevmode\nobreak\ {\bf q}_{j}^{h}]^{\top}% \left(\hat{\bf R}^{\rm BE}[{\bf L}_{j}]_{4:6}\right)^{\wedge},= - [ bold_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_h end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_h end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ] start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âŠ¤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( over^ start_ARG bold_R end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_BE end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT [ bold_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 4 : 6 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ§ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ,

and
